debateinfo.title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1998

cognateinfo.title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE) BILL 1998
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Dr Wooldridge:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The two bills we are now debating, the Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 1998 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Private Health Insurance) Bill 1998 , are supplementary legislation to give effect to the main provisions contained in the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998 . As I have previously indicated, the opposition has a wide range of objections to the proposed 30 per cent rebate. What I want to do now is extend those arguments by highlighting the problems that arise from the way in which the government proposes to implement the rebate as provided for in these two bills. I also want to talk about the anomalies that have been created and the raised expectations that will be dashed when these two bills inevitably go through the House. The underlying issue is the extent to which this government is gambling with taxpayers' money in the hope—and it is no more than a hope, unsupported by any evidence whatsoever—that the rebate will miraculously solve the problems of both the private and the public health systems.

speech.para: For reasons that only the government can explain, the bill which contains the proposed 30 per cent rebate was given the same name as the previous legislation which established the flat, means tested rebate under the Private Health Insurance Incentives Act 1997. Therefore, the bill we are about to consider, the Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 1998, is in fact an amending bill to the earlier act and not to the bill we have recently completed debating. So, to avoid further confusion in the House, I will refer to the two schemes as the old scheme, that is the flat, means tested rebate, and the new scheme, the proposed 30 per cent rebate. As the old scheme is really only 15 months old, we would have to call it the toddler scheme. The government has absolutely no credibility when it comes to health policy, having to change its whole approach every 15 months.

The first of these bills we are now debating abolishes the old scheme—the toddler scheme—which has only been in place by this government for 15 months and provides for the repeal of the old act from the year 2000. This is the shameful part of this government's package. This bill is proof positive that all the government's rhetoric about claiming concern for the elderly is nothing but empty rhetoric and hot air. The bill proves that the government is as heartless as we know it to be.

At present, there is a targeted flat rebate for private health insurance. It is paid to individuals with incomes below $35,000 and to families with incomes below $70,000. They can receive up to $450, depending on the type of insurance they have. This income cut-off level is increased by $3,000 for every child in the family. Just yesterday the minister was carrying on in this House about the level of $70,000 and trying to act as if suddenly the government had realised that people above this level were not people who should be targeted for assistance. The minister must be aware, and certainly other members of the government will be able to inform him, that this is the income level that has been used in all other major legislation as a measure of when a family unit has sufficient income to look after itself and not require target assistance. For example, $70,000 is the cut-off level for this government's family tax initiative and for family payments. So much for the arguments of the minister in that regard.

As for the 700,000 people on incomes below $20,000 over whom we have seen the Prime Minister shed such crocodile tears in the last few days, they are the people who are currently covered by the Private Health Insurance Incentives Scheme, the one that was implemented just last year. They are the ones who should already receive a reduction in their premium. We know what this Prime Minister did to their dental scheme. So much for his concern about their health. It was this Prime Minister who abolished the targeted dental scheme that did so much to help the elderly in this community. That dental scheme saw the pensioners in our community get the urgent dental care they needed. They now know what this government thinks about what they have to do to get dental care—get in the long queues to get urgent dental treatment.

Labor did go to the last election saying that it would retain the old scheme, even though it has failed dismally to increase the level of participation in private health insurance. The Prime Minister boasted at the launch of his then health policy in February 1996 that the old scheme—that is, the targeted health insurance scheme—would increase the proportion of people with private health insurance to 40 per cent. The Prime Minister said that 40 per cent of Australians would take out private health insurance under the scheme that this government now seeks to abolish. That would have seen a rise of 8.4 per cent of Australians taking out health insurance.

The Prime Minister has been proved to be hopelessly wrong. In fact, this government allowed the cost of health insurance to run completely out of control, jumping by over seven per cent two years in a row, and the benefit of the rebate was, of course, immediately wiped out. Participation in health insurance did not rise. In fact, it has dropped by another 1.3 per cent in just the last 15 months.

What has the government learnt from this experience? What has it learnt when it comes to dealing with health insurance? Absolutely nothing. It just wants to pour this incredible amount of taxpayers' money into the same black hole—good money after bad. However, the Labor Party said during the election campaign that we would retain the old scheme to ensure that those least able to afford health insurance got some assistance. That means currently 1.2 million contributors, estimated to cover about two million people, do receive a discount under the old scheme. This represents about one-third of the people who currently have health insurance. Given that we know that higher income groups have a much higher level of health insurance, this represents a very healthy level of assistance.

The reported cost of the old scheme, the one the government is now seeking to abolish, was around $300 million in 1997-98—significantly less than the original estimate. However, there are not yet complete figures on the first full year of operation. This is because it is not yet clear what proportion of people have taken up the assistance as a tax rebate and what proportion have taken it as a reduction in the original premium. I would be pleased if the minister would now make a definitive statement about the expected cost of the old scheme for the year up to June 1998 and a forecast of the remaining cost up to the year 2000 when the bill before us would repeal the old scheme.

After the government announced the new scheme, the 30 per cent rebate, just before the election, the opposition was quick to point out a major flaw in its design. The government had overlooked the fact that not all Australians live in high cost states like Victoria and not all low income people buy blue-ribbon, high cost health insurance products. A quick check by the opposition revealed that there would be a significant number of people for whom the benefits available under the old scheme would actually be greater than the benefits available as a result of the 30 per cent rebate. This would have been particularly the case for people in Western Australia and the Northern Territory where the cost of insurance can be as low as half the cost of insurance in other states. For example, a 30 per cent rebate on a Medibank Private Smart Choice policy in Western Australia would have left that policyholder facing an increase in the premium of over $50 under the original design of the government's scheme.

The government did have enough sense to redesign its proposal on the run to make sure that nobody would be worse off by including in this new scheme a minimum incentive payment equal to what a person would have got under the old scheme. In other words, that person will not get anything extra out of this new rebate, not one cent. Although this amending bill gets rid of the old scheme in the year 2000, the minimum incentive pay ment remains in perpetuity because that had to be put in to protect these people. The government has been quick to assure us that people on the minimum will receive a larger amount very soon because the likely rise in premiums will mean the benefit under the new scheme will rise. I note in passing that this is another area where the government has not provided any evidence, no evidence at all. It has not even provided credible estimates for price increases.

The government is so proud of the built-in inflation that comes with the 30 per cent rebate that it thinks it is a plus that people will get a higher rebate as insurance premiums continue to escalate out of control. The government does not seem to understand, but of course those with health insurance will be very quick to understand, that with premiums rising at three times the inflation rate every year—that is, an eight to 10 per cent price rise every year—another $150 a year would be added to a typical health insurance policy. The 30 per cent rebate would then reduce a typical policy by about $45. The consumer would have to pay the remaining 70 per cent. Therefore, the consumer would pay a rise of $105 a year in insurance premiums.

If the government would only act to ensure that premiums are kept down to maybe even twice the rate of inflation, then the consumer would see a rise of only about $90 a year, but of course the government is not doing anything of the kind. It should be obvious to the government that the benefit to the consumer would be much greater if the government would only act to end the rapid escalation of premiums, rather than locking itself into open-ended growth in premiums with this new rebate.

We only have to look at the history of the old scheme that this bill abolishes to see the way in which the rebate will be wiped out if the underlying economic problems in health insurance are not resolved. The minister has already conceded that premiums will rise again as early as next March. So within three months of the new rebate coming in, we will see the insurance companies taking their first bite out of it.

My calculations are that a person on the old scheme will be, at best, $250 a year better off. At worst, they will be no better off. They will not get one cent extra. Even if they are going to get $250 as a result of the new scheme, that will be wiped out in two years as a result of premium price rises. In two years the result of this massive amount of taxpayers' money will be gone. Premiums will rise and, of course, the people who will have to pay them are those who have private health insurance.

By contrast, a high income person not benefiting from the existing scheme will get a benefit of up to $1,000. So the person who can only afford low cost insurance gets next to nothing, but the high income person who can afford the top table blue-ribbon insurance will get a benefit of up to $1,000. That will take about five years to wipe out the benefit of this 30 per cent rebate. In the end, it will be eliminated because the government is doing nothing at all to address the costs that drive health insurance.

The percentage rebate locks in the rising cost of the scheme and does not protect the consumer. A person paying $1,800 today, not in the old scheme, may see their premium drop by around $500 in the short term, but their premium will be back to $1,800 within five years, judging from past experience. The government shows every sign of repeating its worst mistakes. It is interesting that the minister has made no reference to this substantial imbalance in insurance costs. He should have looked into why the costs in some states are so substantially above costs in other states. We then might have had some effort by the government to address a long-term strategy to bring down the cost of insurance across the nation.

I want to look at the means by which the government proposes to pay the rebate. There are three options provided by the bill. People can receive the rebate as a tax rebate, which is provided in this bill. Alternatively, they can get a reduction in the premium direct from the insurance fund or get a cash refund from the Health Insurance Commission. The first of these two options is available to people under the old scheme. However, it appears the government was concerned that they were not getting enough publicity for the rebate because it was being delivered effectively and indirectly by the insurance funds and the tax office. There has been no rationale put forward by the government—just like everything else that this government puts forward in this area—for adding the cash rebate option. It makes little sense to require people to pay the full amount and then have to claim a cash rebate.

The increased administrative cost for the new scheme is shown in the explanatory memorandum as $14.7 million of taxpayers' money going in to administer this new idea, with an ongoing cost of $7 million after the first year. The government has not been able to provide a breakdown of the costs between the three delivery options. Therefore, we cannot compare the efficiency of these measures. It is understood that the bids have already been made for the provision of the cash rebate, and I understand the Health Insurance Commission views it as a lucrative business. The minister ought to put the cost of providing the cash rebate option on the public record and provide the reasoning for including it when it clearly has not been required in the old scheme, and there has been no public call for this option to be provided.

The reality is that this government wants to get some more publicity for itself, revealing the underlying political intent of this handout, which is to improve the coalition's battered reputation. Ross Gittins said in the Sydney Morning Herald today that this is just an attempt by the government to buy time. He goes on to say:
"Buy" is the operative word. It's hugely expensive, costing $1.2 billion a year on top of the $600 million a year cost of the more limited rebate . . .
`Buy' is absolutely the operative word.

The government has also failed to provide evidence that it promised in relation to the impact on the fringe benefits tax of employers who pay health premiums on behalf of their work force. The tax bill includes a range of provisions in relation to fringe benefits tax that the government has not explained. It is understood that the tax office has provided advice in relation to a possible loophole in this legislation and has recommended that advice be given to employers on how the payment of FBT should occur. I would appreciate it if the minister would table the advice from the tax office and clarify whether the FBT treatment under the tax bill will provide an additional benefit through FBT minimisation.

In summing up, I return to my original concerns about this legislation. It has been a long time since a group of bills has been presented to this parliament proposing the expenditure of such a huge amount of money: $1.5 billion with so little supporting argument—none at all. We have no economic evaluation, no analysis of the impact on the health system, nothing to say that this subsidy will encourage one more person back into private health insurance. In their place, we are offered an opinion poll—that is it for this government—and not even that was independently designed.

What Labor hopes is that the Senate will hear the strength of the arguments against this proposal. If the government does not believe that one extra person will take out private health insurance, then how can they expect this parliament to endorse the expenditure of $1½ billion of taxpayers' money? What we would hope is that the government will be required by the parliament to think more deeply about how health services should be delivered in this country. What we do not want to see is the parliament having to come back in 15 months time with yet another shonky scheme to address the problems of our health system.

This government has obviously got no idea how to address the serious problems that exist in Australia's health system. It thinks that by adding this huge amount of money—really a blank cheque—into health insurance somehow the problems will be resolved.

Yesterday in addressing the 30 per cent rebate, I gave an example of a young man who had had three operations and had been left with large out-of-pocket costs as a result of those operations being conducted in a private hospital. I had a call last night from a fellow in Queensland. He has top level private health insurance. He has a brain tumour and has had to have operations on both of his knees as a result of an accident. In the space of 13 months, this man paid out $11,000 in gaps, in money over and above what he had already paid for his health insurance—$11,000 had to come out of his own pocket to pay for these urgent operations.

As a result of this enormous amount of money that he had to pay, he had to take out a personal loan to cover the repayments. This is what people in the United States are so familiar with. This is the health system that Australians do not want. They do not want a United States health system that says to people that, when you get sick, you are going to have to either mortgage your home or take out a personal loan to pay for essential health care.

What does this government want to do? This government wants to say to Australians, `You're going to have to take out private health insurance to get the essential health care you need. We're not going to put the money into the public hospitals to make sure that, when you get sick, you can get treated.' That is not what this government is all about. What this government wants to do is make sure we go down the United States route, so exemplified by the experience of this person. This government also has no proposals whatsoever to deal with the problem exemplified by this young man. It has no solutions to fixing the problems of gaps or out-of-pocket payments in our private hospitals. If only it did, private health insurance might be a more attractive product.

The Labor Party does not support the provision of percentage discounts for health insurance, as this provides the greatest benefits to those buying the most expensive products. We already have a means tested rebate for low and middle income earners and this has done nothing—absolutely nothing—to increase the participation rate in private health insurance.

As the government itself acknowledges, this new $1.5 billion scheme will not generate a new flood of members to help out the insurance funds. It will not take one person off the public hospital system or off growing waiting lists. That is on the government's own admission. So the government has to look somewhere else for a solution and what it should look at is the cost of insurance. It must control costs; it must get a commitment from the health insurance funds, from the private hospitals and from the medical profession to control costs. The government needs to design a much more effective insurance product for those people who wish to use private hospitals.

The Labor Party remains completely opposed to the creation of a two-class health system. Good hospitals are not a luxury and must never become a luxury that should be restricted to those with the money to pay. That is not what Medicare is all about. Ordinary Australians should not be relegated to second-class medicine delivered at the end of a lengthy queue. Australians want the provision of accessible, quality health care for everybody. That is what Medicare is about. When this government goes out and says it is committed to Medicare, it should understand that that is what it means.

To avoid the wastage of an extra $1½ billion a year in taxpayer subsidies to high income earners, the government should withdraw this bill and pursue a different strategy. It should redirect the funds it had earmarked for this scheme into solving the problems of our public health system. The government should restore the funds that the states have urgently called for to reduce their hospital waiting lists. This would cost an extra $700-odd million on top of the funds the states have so far received. It is half the cost of this rebate proposal. The government should also put back the $100 million to restore the dental health scheme—again, half the amount it proposed to hand out as a rebate on dental claims for those with private health insurance.

The funds that would be swallowed up by the proposal before us should be redirected into the public health system that still remains in crisis. That is where the crisis is and the minister, if he is not aware of it, should go out into the hospitals and have a look at the people on trolleys, have a look at the people who wait for hours in emergency departments because no beds are available in our public hospitals.

There is an urgent need for a range of targeted programs to restore patient care levels. But, if this proposal does not get through the parliament, is the minister going to do what the public is calling for and put the money into our public hospitals? No, what he wants to do is take his bat and ball and go home. In a fit of pique, he will say, `No, if the parliament won't let me have my way, the public isn't going to get anything, the public health system won't get anything. It doesn't matter whether there is $1½ billion to spend on health, we're certainly not going to put it into the public hospitals where it counts.'

That really sums up this government's approach to the health policy. If anything does, it is that statement by this health minister. He is prepared to put $1½ billion into a scheme that will not encourage one extra person into private health insurance, but he will not put it into public hospitals where he must know that it would urgently treat so many people who are desperate to get the care they need. If the government proceeds, it must be aware that all Australians will be watching and holding it accountable for the inevitable failure of this scheme to achieve what the Private Hospitals Association has set as a target for the government.

The private hospitals want private health insurance back up to 45 per cent. That is what they want to see this scheme achieve. What we would say to the government is: if you do not achieve that target, if you do not keep the scheme within budget and you do not put an end to public hospital waiting lists, this will yet again be another example of this government's failure when it comes to health policy.

For the bulk of the community, public hospitals through Medicare provide the security of a high quality hospital service. That is what they want. They want to be treated in the public hospitals, which do such a fantastic job. If this government was really sincere about its commitment not to undermine Medicare, then it should agree to abandon this ill-conceived, completely poorly argued proposal, which has no supporting evidence whatsoever. Instead of taking the bat and ball and all of the money back to the budget, the government should put the money into the public health system where it is so urgently needed.

talk.start.para: —Over the last few days, we have heard numerous maiden speeches from the new members of this place. Many of these speeches have contained references to the members' intentions to represent the views and aspirations of those who elected them, as we all should do. I took the time to extract a few of the remarks made in this place by some of the newly elected members. The member for Oxley in Queensland said:

speech.para: Through listening to the people of Oxley, I feel I am then able to speak—and speak not to the people but for the people of Oxley.
The Labor member for Griffith made a similar remark:
I am in this place, first and foremost, as a representative of my local community . . .
The member for Lilley said:
My commitment to them
referring to his electors—
is to work hard, to listen to their views and to strongly represent their interests in this place.
Back in 1990, when the then Senator Kernot gave her maiden speech—of course, as a Democrat in those days; she has since changed her spots—she said:
The honour of being elected by the people of Queensland to represent them in this chamber is immense and goes without question.

No doubt their electors would have been reassured by these words. But, in fact, in the first division that we had today—the very first division in this 39th parliament—every member of the opposition neglected to represent the views of the people they represent and voted with their feet and tried to defeat a worthy representation of a measure that will go a long way to helping hundreds of thousands of Australians.

Currently, 980,000 Queenslanders have private health insurance. Not one Queensland member of the Labor Party in this chamber got to their feet to utter one word in defence of their reasons for voting against this meas ure—not one member. That is a disgrace and a blight upon the electorates they have now been elected to represent.
Mr Griffin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Not one Queensland member of this opposition had the guts to stand in their place—

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The member for Longman has the call.
—He is wrong!
—I call the parliamentary secretary at the table to order. The member for Longman has the call.

—Not one Queensland member had the guts to stand in this place and defend their decision to oppose this measure. Not one Queensland member wants to explain to their constituents why they deserted them on this issue.

speech.para: I would normally restrict my remarks to looking after the electorate of Longman, where there are 23,223 who currently hold private health insurance, but there is a bigger issue: there are 980-odd thousand Queenslanders who need to have a voice in this place, people who are already being seen by the first division in this place as having been neglected by those opposite. They are the 29,704 people who have private health insurance in the electorate of Bowman; the 28,273 people who hold it in the seat of Brisbane; the 38,230 people—or 48 per cent of the population—in Capricornia; some 30,275 electors—or 39 per cent of the population—in Dickson, my neighbouring electorate; some 33,394 people in Lilley; 20,836 in Oxley; and a further 21,439 people in the seat of Rankin.

There can be no good reason for the deafening silence of the members opposite other than to support their beleaguered leader who was painted into a corner on this issue. The ALP is again divided on ideological lines. This is not the first time they have been divided on such lines—
Ms Macklin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —on the basis of the decisions of the member for Jagajaga who interjects. The fact is that the ALP policy on this issue is being run by an ideologue, a true socialist, in the member for Jagajaga, who proves time and time again on social issues how Left she can possibly be. This is the woman who, having just cost the ALP an election with her capital gains tax proposal, is readying herself to apply the next loss to the ALP through this stand.

speech.para: The fact is that the member for Jagajaga wants to tax people's holiday homes. She wants to tax people's silver—the grandparents. These are the stands that she has taken in the past and the stands that she will take in the future. Of course, that decision, supported blindly by those opposite during the last campaign—and many of them will tell you in the hallways in this place that it cost them dearly at the last election—has now been rejected. So how long will it be before the policy that they come in here to denounce today will also be rejected by those opposite? I hope for their sake it is only the two to three weeks that it took them in the past to recognise the folly of their ways.

The member for Jagajaga and the Leader of the Opposition are condemning many of those who sit opposite to be `oncers'. Let me assure these members that we will be pointing out to their constituents time and time again over the next three years what their local Labor member of parliament has done and how they have been represented in this place.

Whatever the faults of the Australian Labor Party, they have proven themselves to be pragmatists on occasions. Who can forget Graham Richardson's ethos, `Whatever it takes'? He was the man who represented them as the minister for health in this place and who was denounced by those opposite in the chamber here today. Mr Richardson is one of the many critics of the ALP's ideological position on this particular proposal. If I were one of the Labor backbenchers sitting on a small or medium margin, I would be very nervous that Labor's policies on an important issue like health are being hijacked by the `loony Left'.

Unfortunately for them and for all of Australia, the consequences go much further than to just those people who hold private health insurance. The refusal of those opposite to support this measure has profound consequences that go way beyond the immediate impact. It will mean, on average, a loss of $8.9 million of additional household expenditure per electorate. That will result in school shoes for children that might otherwise have been purchased not being purchased. It will mean that state schools like Narangba and Strathpine in the seat of the member for Dickson not being replaced. It may result in parents purchasing less fruit and vegetables for their children, or perhaps not allowing their children to participate in a sporting activity, which of course also has a profound impact on children's health—all because Labor is locked into an unsustainable, ideological position by the member for Jagajaga.

It will not be just those who will miss out on this rebate who will be the losers; it will be the shopkeepers, the bakers, the butchers, the small business community, who add to the wealth and the health of their communities by providing jobs.

The Labor Party is also denying the wider community the benefits that this rebate will deliver. I realise the member for Dickson has not lived for very long in the area that she now represents. However, surely she is aware that neither the Caboolture nor the Redcliffe hospitals would cope even if a small percentage of those currently contributing to their own health needs were to opt out and rely on these two hospitals.

There are in excess of 84,000 people currently covered by private health insurance in the electorates of Longman, Petrie and Dickson alone. Does the member for Dickson seriously believe that any public hospital system could cope if, as Labor would have it, these people took Labor's ideological approach and said, `No more, the state can look after me'?

And the argument that the government should spend more on public hospitals simply does not stack up. Australians currently contribute $4.5 billion per year via private hospital insurance to the health system. Given that the percentage of the population having private hospital insurance halved under Labor administration, then it is logical to conclude that in today's terms that represents a loss of approximately $4.5 billion in voluntary health contributions.

It is no wonder that this government has had to increase health spending via the Medicare agreement by 19 per cent, or $7.2 billion, over the next five years to make up for this gap. Of course, if nothing is done to redress the decreasing numbers paying private health insurance then this money will not build on the current hospital system and improve it but simply be used to prop up the overstretched current system.

The thing that really highlights the opposition's hypocrisy on this issue was their constant condemnation of the existing incentive scheme throughout the last parliament. Their then spokesman constantly came to the dispatch box telling all and sundry that this was a failed scheme and should be abandoned. But what did they do during the election? The fact is that they supported the very scheme that they as an opposition had condemned for 2½ years. They said it did not work, yet they want to continue it. If that is not hypocrisy, I do not know what is.

The facts are that Labor, over 13 years, systematically destroyed private health insurance. That was one of the major factors behind the deterioration of the national health system whilst they were in government. They took private health insurance to all time lows. They removed the rebates that were there. They removed the bed day subsidies that were there. Why? Because the member for Jagajaga was also advising on these issues in opposition and her ideology was being driven through these policy decisions.

Now we have a situation where not one of the eight Queensland Labor members in this chamber will stand up for their constituents. Why were they not prepared to stand here and defend the stance that they took on the floor of the chamber on the first division of this 39th Parliament? This is not the time to go missing in action. This is the time to say no to the ideologically driven member for Jagajaga, who seems to be getting her way more and more in the Labor Party of 1998. But there is something that the members opposite can do and, more importantly, there is something that the electors in the seats of Bowman, Lilley, Brisbane, Oxley, Capricornia, Rankin, Griffith and Dickson can do. They can petition their senators. They can petition their Labor senators and say, `Enough is enough. You've made your point. We don't like your point. We rejected it at the last election. We want you now to stand up in the Senate and support the government's legislation. We want you to support the fact that this government has increased Medicare funding to the states by 17½ per cent. We want you to support the government's stance so that we can retain the hard-won money that we put into our own private health insurance. It is a choice that we make for a better quality of life for us, but it has a spin-off for all of the community.'

If the 980,000 Queenslanders who currently take out private health insurance were to reject it tomorrow, our hospital system would collapse. There is no doubt about that. That is why we are in the strife we are today, because they were the policies that Labor followed for 13 years. I encourage all Queenslanders to speak loudly to all Queensland Labor senators. Send them a clear message that the time has come for them to support this piece of legislation and do an about-turn, as they so often do, after the member for Jagajaga's ideologically driven leftist approach is seen to have been defeating both the Labor Party and good governance.
