talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Having concluded that question, the blue and the standing orders suggest that, with it being past 2 p.m., we now should proceed to question time before moving to the third reading. Is that not the case?
—We have just agreed the resolution that the question be now put. Therefore, the chair has no choice but to put the question and then move to question time.
—(Inaudible )
—Would the member for Fraser resume his seat. The question was that the question be put. The House has now resolved to put the question, and I intend to put the question that the bill be agreed to.
—I might be wrong, Mr Speaker, but I thought—
—Order! The member for Dobell has the call, and he is entitled, as is every other member in this House, to be heard in silence.
—I thought the question was, `Is it the wish of the House to proceed to consideration in detail forthwith?' I thought that was the question before the House.

—As the member for Dobell will understand, having come into the chair I was very anxious to find that I had the right question. So I checked with both the Deputy Speaker and the Clerk. We have just resolved the question that the question be put, which was proposed by the minister for health. We now have to put the question, and the question that needs to be put is that the bill be agreed to. The question is that the bill be agreed to.
—I concede the point of the member for Fraser that it is now past 2 p.m. It being past 2 p.m., consideration of the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, is it not the fact that the Australian Taxation Office provided to the government's tax reform task force earlier this year evidence of a new generation of tax rorts and the risk they pose to the revenue base? Is it not also a fact that the tax office has provided advice to the government on options for legislative change to combat those new rorts? Will the government act on this advice, or will the Prime Minister once again allow a telephone book of warnings and submissions on tax rorts from the tax commissioner to accumulate while he does nothing—just as he did when he was Treasurer in the Fraser government?
—The Leader of the Opposition has put his question.
—Mr Speaker—

—Treasurer, I have not called you because I have not as yet had sufficient silence for me to consider that you were being offered the courtesy that should be extended to every member of the House. I call the Treasurer to respond to the Leader of the Opposition's question.
—What? Is he going to show you up again, John?
—Order! The member for Batman!

—The Leader of the Opposition has in the last two question times and today referred to comments that have been made by Michael Carmody, the Commissioner of Taxation, on new generation type tax schemes in a speech that he gave to the chartered accountants in business congress of 1998. In the course of that speech, Mr Carmody indicated that he was worried about tax effective investments. He stated:

answer.para: In June of this year I spoke of our concerns about the huge growth in a range of tax effective investments in such things as research, films and primary production. To give you some idea of what I mean, the level of deductions in that year—
associated with arrangements we have most concern about is in excess of $1 billion.
Mr Carmody is an independent statutory officer. Having become aware of those schemes, he is now investigating them and taking action.

I am aware that he is taking action because I have had numbers of complaints from members of parliament that he is taking too aggressive action. For example, I have a complaint from the member for Fremantle on 5 June 1998 complaining about the Commissioner of Taxation investigating one such scheme. I have a complaint from Daryl Melham, the member for Banks, on 11 June 1998 about the action that the commissioner was taking. I have a complaint from Mr Rod Sawford of 15 June about the action that the commissioner was taking. I have a complaint from Robert McClelland on 16 June 1998 about the action the commissioner was taking.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Treasurer will refer to members by their electorates as well.
—I have a complaint from the member for Throsby on 22 June about the activity. I could go on. I have a complaint from the member for Hunter on 29 July 1998 which states:

answer.para: I make representation on behalf of 12 families in my electorate. They have been hit for six by the Australian Taxation Commissioner's recent ruling with respect to investment in the film Clockers . Your intervention in the matter will be very much appreciated.

So we have the Leader of the Opposition saying, `What is the government doing about these tax plans?' and his backbenchers are running around saying, `Stop them, please stop them!' When you give away economic credibility, you only make a mockery of your own position.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House if he is aware of claims the government's tax reform plan will have an adverse effect on the level of employment in Australia? What is the Treasurer's response to such reports?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and for his interest in legitimate tax reform. It has been argued and I think it is pretty clear that the government's tax reform, which is a proposal to take taxes off business inputs and to take taxes off Australian exports, will lead to the creation of jobs. Our proposal to improve business taxation in this country and to reduce personal income tax rates for average Australians down to 30 per cent will be great for incentive.

answer.para: One has to follow the claims of the Labor Party, which apparently is prepared to make any claim to try to justify its reactionary position in relation to tax, and they normally take a few days to track down. The member for Hotham has been running around the country saying that tax reform costs jobs. His first authority for that proposition was based on a work by Dr Colin Hargreaves, who put out a statement on the Internet under the name of the Economic Modelling Bureau of Australia, which the Press Gallery will recall the Labor Party hawked about before the election. They hawked about a document saying that the Economic Modelling Bureau of Australia had on its board of reference Vince FitzGerald, Ross Garnaut and Chris Murphy. When Ross Garnaut was made aware of this claim, he put out a statement saying:

We regret the way in which this paper on the effects of a GST on jobs has been associated with the ANU. In our opinion, the economic analysis on a GST on jobs is not reflective of the high standards of the ANU.
Mr Vince FitzGerald, who also had his name taken in vain in support of this claim, put out a public letter saying:
I am writing to let you know that I no longer wish to be on the board of the EMBA, if indeed there is an EMBA.

Mr Chris Murphy also put out a statement saying that any attempt to try to link the tax reform with the loss of jobs was erroneous. When the member for Hotham put out the claim, first of all based on Dr Hargreaves—all of whose referees walked away—and said it would cost jobs, he then made this claim:
. . . Access Economics . . . say it will cost 130,000 jobs.

That was Simon Crean talking to Fran Kelly on Radio National on 12 November 1998. I have now contacted Access Economics. They say that the modelling that they have done on the government's tax reform package creates in its first year an additional 23,000 jobs, an additional 21,000 in the year after that, an additional 54,000 in the year after that and 190,000 new jobs in the first decade, and the member for Hotham went on ABC radio and quoted Access Economics as saying it will cost jobs. It always takes a few days, but you can run these claims. I say to the journalists, before you publish them, give us a few days to run them down. You can always run them down.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Treasurer will address his remarks to the Speaker, not to the journalists.

—We have this extraordinary situation where the Australian Labor Party now say that they need four inquiries into the government's tax plan before they can vote against it. They are opposed to the government's tax plan and they are going to vote against it under all the circumstances, and that is why they need five months to inquire into it!

answer.para: The Australian Labor Party had to conduct a ballot as to who would actually be their chairman on this inquiry. As AM reported this morning:
But it's hardly a sign of the future, is it, when your key Economic Committee Chairman's drawn from a hat after a battle of the factions?

talk.start.para: —That is something the Liberal Party does not do. The Prime Minister appoints them. The supine backbench.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition!
—He always yells loudest when he is in the most trouble. Mr Crean answered:

answer.para: Well, I think that shows a pretty evenly divided Caucus situation . . .
He said:
. . . it's not the first time decisions like this have been drawn from a hat . . .

Labor making up its tax policy—drawing from a hat! Labor finding its economic chairman—drawing from a hat! Labor finding talent from its backbench—drawing from a hat! This is high farce from a group of people who will not confront the issues that the Australian public voted on. Pass the tax plan.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Banking Services

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, the only farce was yesterday's policy on the run by the Treasurer in relation to bank—
—If the member for Hotham does not move to his question, he will resume his seat.

—My question is to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen reports that the Australian Bankers Association is seeking a GST on a wide range of financial services? Has he seen reports that the ABA Chief Executive, Tony Aveling, has ruled out seeking a GST on normal bank account fees only `at the current time'? Will the Treasurer assure the House that he will never ever levy a GST on ordinary consumer bank account and transaction fees?

—Of course I am aware that the Australian Bankers Association sought to bring financial services into the scope of the GST, and they were informed no. That is why our policy says it will not happen. As I said yesterday, on several occasions, the ABA sought to come into the GST system. Why? Many businesses seek to come into the GST system because they actually find that it helps them. After considering it, the government said no, and that is the policy.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, given the very positive expectation for further employment growth in the small business sector that was contained in the Yellow Pages small business survey yesterday, could you inform the House of any impediments that stand in the way of businesses taking on extra people? Are you aware of recent comments by business people raising concerns about impediments to employment?

—I thank the honourable member for Dawson for her question. There has been survey after survey after survey of the small business community, and they are saying one thing quite clearly: they would like to employ more people but they are genuinely concerned about the unfair dismissal system. We have gone a fair way to reforming it, but there is absolutely no doubt that we could create more jobs in the Australian community if we could provide a fairer deal for small business, and that means the passage of the legislation which we put to the House and which is critical to the creation of up to 50,000 jobs—on the advice of the independent small business community.

answer.para: The fact is that there is an impediment to creating more jobs in this economy, and that impediment is the Labor Party, because they are opposed to doing things which would assist the small business community. They not only created the problem but they are now opposed to the fixing of the problem. It is the Labor Party, with a frontbench stacked with ex-ACTU presidents and trade union hacks. The Queensland Teachers Union now has the shadow portfolio. The deputy leader is an ex-ACTU hack—as is the shadow minister for finance. You have all these ex-union people running the Labor Party and stopping the creation of jobs in the small business community.

We have of course provided a briefing to the shadow minister on the unfair dismissal law. We are also prepared to provide a briefing to the new shadow minister for small business. We would hope that the Labor Party might finally put ideology aside and realise that jobs are more important, and that this measure for the benefit of small business really would create jobs. That offer is there for the shadow minister. I am not sure that he needs a briefing from us, because he was asked recently on the Sunday program what perceptions there were in the small business community about unfair dismissal and I am very pleased to say that in responding to this question he said that his own family had had some experience of the unfair dismissal law. This is what he said:
Well my wife constantly tells me she could afford to put on one person or would like to put on one more person, but is fearful of unfair dismissals . . .

That was a pretty fair comment to make. Commonsense dictates that this is a measure which will create jobs in the small business community. These people know that that would do so, but it is only the ACTU and the ex-union types on Labor's frontbench which is preventing the passage of that legislation.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Banking Fees

talk.start.para: —My question again is to the Treasurer. Treasurer, yesterday under pressure you ruled out a GST—
—Ha, ha!

—He doesn't think it's pressure. This man deludes himself. Yesterday under pressure you ruled out a GST on fees for opening and maintaining bank accounts. With regard to the following clearly identifi able mortgage service fees, will your GST apply to loan application fees, loan establishment fees, mortgage insurance fees and real estate valuation fees?

—As I made entirely clear yesterday on several occasions, financial services are input taxed and there is no GST on their outputs. That is, there is no GST on the financial service—or the fee for the financial service, as I also said to you. Where a bank provides a service for competitive neutrality purposes which is subject to a GST because the product is sold by somebody else, such as insurance or—the other example I gave to you—financial advice, the GST will apply to that. If that was a case of being under pressure yesterday—oh, we love it! Put us under such pressure every day.
—We saw you under pressure during the campaign, Pete!
—Is there a GST on Panadol?
—The member for Batman, members on my right and the member for Jagajaga will not engage in cross-parliamentary exchange.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware of recent comments from the Australian Medical Association and others that the survival of Australia's public hospital system depends on the survival of the private health system, and therefore the rebate for people with private health insurance should be widely supported? What is the minister's response to these comments and is he aware of any alternative plans being put forward to ensure that Australia's balanced system of health care survives into the 21st century?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware of the AMA's comments. They came from the deputy president, Dr Sandra Hacker. The AMA, of course, is not a body that always agrees with what the government is doing and has been quite prepared to say so in the past. I am also aware of some comments made today by a former national president of the Labor Party, Neil Batt. He has put out a press release which says the following:

answer.para: When Labor was developing Medicare—
and he was around; he was on the national executive of the Labor Party from 1974 to 1980—

it was always predicated on the need for a significant private health insurance membership base. We knew that the public hospitals and the tax system would not be able to cope if private health insurance levels fell too low. The Labor Party that gave Australia Medicare would never have declared war on private health insurance. It accepted the right of all Australians to have choice. By denying 5.3 million Australians a tangible benefit, Labor is itself responsible for every adverse health outcome in Australia.

Mr Batt is not the first Labor person who has come out in support of the government's proposal. It follows on from Graham Richardson, the former Labor health minister, who last Friday said that the Labor Party's position was illogical and ideological, and it follows on from comments made previously by Peter Beattie, now the Labor Premier of Queensland, who said, `Everybody knows that the public system would be better off if there were more people in private health insurance.'

The honourable member also asked me if I knew about any other proposals. I have to say that I do not, because there is no other proposal on the table. The Labor Party went to the last election with private health insurance on the backburner. It did not understand it. It was not able to come up with a policy so it went to the election with nothing—30 per cent of the health insurance system in Australia with nothing.

So there is no alternative. There is not any organisation or body putting forward alternatives. You have a whingeing, carping, bellicose opposition. You have an after-dinner speech from the Leader of the Opposition. Can't you just imagine it: the Chinese takeaway, the bottle of red and him watching the television, seeing the debate coming on and saying, `I've got to get in there and talk,' and then giving a speech with no substance at all. That reflects your policy—no substance.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Are the cost estimates of the impact of the private health insurance rebate legislation based on the assumption of no increase in membership of private health insurance funds and no increase in premiums by those funds?

—The government clearly indicated to the Australian people before the last election the importance of private health cover. It indicated that it was prepared to ensure that that would occur by providing funding, and of course that has been the subject of some considerable debate. A number of modellings have been done on it.
—Oh, there are! When are they going to be provided?
—Clearly, there are always modellings done and there is a proposition—

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The minister has the call.

—You clearly don't want the answer. You don't want to know the answer; you want to play silly games, as you have at all times on private health cover. You are not interested in seeing that we have a viable health system in this country. The government has made its decision and that decision was given to the Australian people beforehand. It was verified, unlike Labor promises before the last election where they were not prepared under the charter of budget honesty to put forward their fundings for costing.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order relating to relevance. There was a specific question asked about whether or not the calculations that are to be put out in public were based on an assumption that there would be no increase in membership and no increase in the premiums. The question is: is it based on that?—nothing else.
—I rule that the minister is in order, after all he is dealing with the whole question of private health insurance.
—The minister is in order.

—As I indicated, the matter that the government put before the Australian people was costed by Finance. When Finance costs any matter that the government makes a decision on, it is based on reasonable assumptions, it is based on objective assumptions and in this instance it factors in the current levels of premiums and the take-up rate that would be applicable. The outcome is that the government has announced the cost that is there—
—Mr Speaker—
—Oh, sit down. It is based on all of the reasonable objective analysis that has been done, which the government accepts.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order relating to relevance. The minister has indicated that he has the figures. What are they? What are the assumptions that he has made his costings on?
—The member for Jagajaga knows she is asking, as it were, a supplementary question. The minister has answered the question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. What is the government doing to expand quality training for real jobs? Is the minister aware of alternative proposals in relation to training, including calls for intellectual renewal? What is the minister's response to those proposals?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Moreton for his question. I appreciate it. I am still waiting for Mike Pezzullo and John Angley to write one for the shadow minister.
—The minister will come to the question he has been asked.

—The Commonwealth has delivered since 1997 a total of 70,000 places in TAFE over and above the places that existed before then at no cost to the Commonwealth taxpayer. The Commonwealth has achieved these additional places as a result of its policy of growth through efficiencies.

answer.para: In the course of the election campaign and since, I have become aware of an alternative approach to TAFE places. The Labor Party, in the butchered education policy that it put before the people, promised a meagre 10,000 additional places in TAFE over three years at a cost of $120 million to the taxpayer. In other words, the coalition through good government can deliver 70,000 additional places at no cost to the taxpayer; the Labor Party is going to sting the taxpayer for $120 million for a mere 10,000 additional places.

This shows the utter incompetence of the policy that the Labor Party put before the people at the last election. It is no wonder that the Leader of the Opposition is now calling for intellectual renewal within the Labor Party. What must his frontbench be thinking about this appeal of the Leader of the Opposition? As the little Red Indian from Werriwa said on 2BL on 7 October:

What's the point of being a shadow minister to spend 18 months consulting closely with interest groups? What's the point of just going through what you think is a legitimate process in the party? What's the point of putting it down when you think of the quality format, to have it rewritten by someone in the leader's office who hadn't been involved in education policy at any part of the last 2½ years?

The Labor Party's problem is that they have now got an education policy on the back bench without a spokesman, and they have a spokesman on the front bench without a policy. We all welcome the call for intellectual renewal, but it is a big job before the policy butchers in the Leader of the Opposition's office to deliver it.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. The finance minister would be aware that currently 30.3 per cent of the population have private health cover. What increase in the take-up rate has been assumed in the costing of your new private health insurance rebate?
—I bet he doesn't answer this one either.
—The member for Paterson has a propensity to interject that is only rivalled by his predecessors.
—As I indicated a short time ago, clearly all members opposite would dearly love to see the hospital system break down. They have never supported private health cover.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. There was a very specific question asked here and only that question, nothing to justify a ramble on. And that question was: what are the assumptions on the take-up rate? That was the question. He says he has the figures.
—I very nearly ruled this question out of order on the grounds that it had been fully answered.
—How can you rule it out on that basis when he has not answered the previous one?
—I am not here to enter into a debate with the member for Dobell. I merely indicate that the minister for finance has the call, and the answer is entirely in the minister for finance's hands.

—Clearly, if the government did nothing, the fallout rate would be very significant, the drop-out rate would be very significant, and this government is not prepared to allow that to happen. My recollection is that there would be an increase in the uptake, the exact details of that uptake I am not sure of but I will find out. I cannot recollect the exact increase of the uptake from the current 30.3 per cent. I will find out, and I will inform the Leader of the Opposition very soon.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister inform the House why the Australian government did not support the United Nations resolution entitled `Towards a nuclear-weapons free world: the need for a new agenda', and whether the government has lessened its commitment to the eventual elimination of nuclear weapons.

—I thank the honourable member for Forde for her question. I recognise her interest in these issues and the interests that many members of the coalition have in nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament. The short answer to the honourable member's question is that this government looks to achieve practical outcomes in foreign policy. We will support proposals that we think will help to advance the cause of nuclear non-proliferation and the eventual elimination of nuclear weapons.

answer.para: We did promote the Canberra Commission's report. I presented it to the United Nations General Assembly, I presented it to the United Nations Conference on Disarmament, and it was circulated to all relevant foreign ministries—just about all foreign ministries—around the world. One of the conclusions of the Canberra Commission's report—which I suspect on the opposition side has only been read by the member for Holt, the man whom the Labor Party wants to hold an inquiry into now—was that the nuclear weapons states themselves had to act to eliminate nuclear weapons.

The truth is that action has been taken in the right direction. During the course of this decade, the United States and Russia have halved their holdings of nuclear weapons. We have high expectations that the Russian Duma will ratify the START II agreement so that START II will come into force and START III will be under way as well.

But we have been doing more than that. We have been out there promoting the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty. The achievements of the Australian government in bringing to life that treaty will stand as one of the great monuments to non-proliferation by Australia. We are also in the process of promoting the Fissile Material Cut-Off Treaty, and I have very great optimism that, during the course of next year, a treaty can be concluded in the Conference on Disarmament.

The new agenda proposal put forward by a number of countries has many features that are attractive, but it is an agenda which is ill-defined. It includes, for example, the proposal for an international conference on disarmament and the elimination of nuclear weapons. Frankly, we believe that to hold such a conference now would complicate the work being done to promote the Fissile Material Cut-Off Treaty and to conclude the further signatories of the comprehensive test-ban treaty.

There are some people of goodwill in this parliament who support the new agenda proposal and I recognise, in many cases, their goodwill. But I have gone to the trouble to find out where the Labor Party stands on this issue. I could find no reference at all to where the Labor Party stood on the new agenda. It has done no policy work whatsoever on this important issue. They set up the Canberra Commission and, since then, they have done absolutely nothing. They are a policy vacuum on one of the key issues that the international community is facing.

But then I hesitated because I did find that the Labor Party had done something. A few weeks ago they supported a resolution in the Senate promoting the new agenda. But did the Labor Party put up the motion? No, Senator Margetts did. So the Labor Party's policy in so far as it exists is written by none other than Senator Margetts.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Will the minister make the several modelling options to which he referred in his answer available to the parliament before further consideration of the legislation?
—The government has accepted a proposal. The acceptance of that proposal is part of the legislation before this parliament at the present time. That is the only issue that is relevant to this debate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Can the minister please advise the House of the status of the Productivity Commission report into the pig and pig meat industries on the safeguard actions against imports? What steps will the minister be taking as a result of the commission's findings?

—I thank the honourable member for Riverina for her question. As all members of the House would be aware, the pig and pig meat industries in Australia have been in a bit of turmoil and suffering from low commodity prices in recent times. As a result of that, we commissioned an inquiry by the Productivity Commission into whether safeguard actions should be applied. That report has been tabled in the parliament today. It contains a number of findings which we will now be consulting with representatives of the pig meat industry about prior to formulating our response to the report.

answer.para: There has been a fair bit of debate about this issue. I think what should be noted are some of the circumstances that have existed in the past that caused this circumstance. People should note that the Labor Party removed the tariff from this industry in the early 1990s without providing any assistance to industry to adjust.

talk.start.para: —Did you oppose it?
—They removed that tariff and they did not provide any assistance to adjust.
—Did you?
—Earlier this year—
—Tell us whether you opposed it.
—The member for Melbourne persists in interjecting. I will not warn him again today.

—Earlier this year, our government announced a $19 million package of assistance to help the industry adjust to the international marketplace and to help it focus on international marketing and exports. It is instructive to note that in the last 12 months exports of pig meat from Australia have actually increased by 84 per cent.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it not a fact that you have so little confidence in your new $1.5 billion a year health fund rebate that you have assumed it will generate no increase whatsoever in private health cover? If not, what is your new target?
—The answer to the first question is that the Leader of the Opposition is incorrect. I have been informed that the assumed rise on which the calculation has been made is to a figure of 33 per cent.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It should not be necessary for the Speaker to rise in order to achieve some sort of civility in the chamber.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Would the minister inform the House of the initiatives this government has introduced in the area of youth traineeships and apprenticeships? As the school year comes to a close, how will those initiatives assist young Australians to make the transition from school to employment?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Parramatta for his question. I acknowledge his great interest in the future of young people in his electorate. The coalition is committed to giving all young Australians the best possible opportunities in life through the education and training system. That is why we put in place our national literacy reforms. It is why we are providing a pathway from work to school. It is why we are maintaining junior wage rates so that young people can compete for the jobs that are available.

answer.para: As we approach the end of the school year, many thousands of young people will have the opportunity to take advantage of the government's training reforms. The government has put in place a new national training system that provides young people with national, portable, recognised qualifications for jobs. This year, over 200,000 people will be participating in the new apprenticeship system. I should tell young people that new apprenticeships are available now not just in the traditional trades. They are available across the whole range of new industries, such as information technology, communications and multimedia as well as in areas such as sport, recreation and finance. There are now some 60 new apprenticeship centres available throughout Australia. I invite young people to inquire at these centres about what opportunities are available to them in their areas.

This year, the government is also funding some 80 job pathway brokers, who will be assisting some 1,400 schools and the school leavers at those schools to move effectively from school to jobs. This government is committed to the future of young Australians. This government has policies. The other side of the House has a massive, gaping policy vacuum. We are determined that young people will have opportunities.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has just now confirmed to the House that we have a $1.5 billion per annum expenditure to lift the private health coverage of the population from 30.3 to 33.0 per cent.
—You questions?

—How do you expect the House to believe that the further underpinning of this figure is based on an assumption that, as the Minister for Finance said, there will be no premium increase? What arrangements and agreements have you entered into to ensure that, in order to sustain your figuring, there is no premium increase?
—The assumption on which the Leader of the Opposition's question is based is wrong.
—Where is it wrong?

—It is completely wrong. Not only do I call it wrong, but Graham Richardson calls it wrong as well. The reality is that, unless further action is taken, there will be a further catastrophic decline in the number of people taking out private health insurance in this country. That is exactly what the Australian Labor Party wants. The Australian Labor Party is opposed to private health insurance. That is why Graham Richardson was driven to say this on 23 November this year:

answer.para: I don't understand why Labor can't simply stand up and say—yes we do need to have a system of private health.

The reason that Labor will not stand up and say that is that Labor does not believe, in its modern manifestation, that we should have a system of private health insurance. The incentive that the government has proposed, an incentive that will help 700,000 people who are on—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance.
—There is no frivolity in this.
—The Prime Minister will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition has the call.
—Mr Speaker, I have asked a direct question based on the government's assumption—
—And I am giving a direct answer.
—No, we are not getting an answer to the question. Having now got out the figuring in relation to the increase in coverage, I asked a question—
—The point of order?
—It goes to relevance. We are now trying to get the assumptions—
—I will rule on relevance.
—That was the question, and nothing else.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat, and I will rule on relevance.
—Mr Speaker—

—One moment, Prime Minister. The Leader of the Opposition, along with any other member, has the right to a point of order on relevance at any time, as he knows. He does not have the right, and neither does the Speaker, to instruct how the question will be answered. It is not reasonable to say that the Prime Minister's answer on private health insurance was not relevant to the question.

—The money that is involved in the new 30 per cent tax reduction that the Australian people voted for on 3 October will obtain three benefits. It will, on the assumptions that have been made, lead to an increase in the number of people who are taking out private health insurance. It will also achieve a very, very significant cost saving to the Commonwealth if it prevents a further burden being thrown on the public purse by the additional strain on the public hospital system if there is a further fall in the number of people who are privately insured.

answer.para: What the Labor Party has done is to watch the steady decline, year over year, of the number of people in private health insurance. When Richardson was your health minister, he warned you that if this fell below 40 per cent you would have a problem, and Carmen Lawrence, Paul Keating and Kim Beazley rubbed their hands together and said, `Terrific, let's have the problem, because we don't believe in private health insurance.'

talk.start.para: —I am the member for Fremantle.
—And year after year under Labor the number of people—

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —We may not like every minute of it, but we also want a bit of relevance. Mr Speaker, my point of order is to relevance. There was a very specific question asked here, and there is control under the standing orders in the hands of the Speaker on relevance and a capacity to give an interpretation on it. This cover-up smokescreen is a million miles from an answer.

—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. What the Prime Minister has been saying is entirely relevant to the question of private health insurance. The Prime Minister has the call. I should, however, Prime Minister, indicate that the member for Fremantle did—while by interjection and therefore not really deserving this level of tolerance—make the point that she was entitled to be referred to by her seat, and I do reinforce that point.

—I apologise to the member for Fremantle for not referring to her as the member for Fremantle. But the member for Fremantle, the then finance minister in the Labor government and now Leader of the Opposition, and the then Prime Minister in the Labor government all rubbed their hands together and said, `Let's have a crisis in private health insurance because we do not believe in it.'

answer.para: The Australian people have a very clear choice: you either invest more money in private health insurance and preserve it as a viable alternative for middle Australia or let it die as an available option for middle Australia. You restrict it entirely to the very wealthy who will always be able to afford to take it out and you load onto the public hospital system of this country the health needs of the overwhelming bulk of the Australian community. That is what the Labor Party wants. The Labor Party wants a two-tiered health system in this country. It wants a health system that will always be able to be afforded by the very wealthy and it wants the rest to compete for the resources of the public hospital system.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker—
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Prime Minister, I would imagine, is winding up his answer.

—The Prime Minister is winding up his answer. I am winding up to my answer, Mr Speaker. Can I just say we have that very clear choice: either you have a balanced system where there is fair access for middle Australia to private health insurance or you turn your back on private health insurance, surrender it to the very wealthy and leave the rest of the community with the public system. I do not think that is fair, we will never think it is fair, and that is why we are committing these resources to give middle Australia the opportunity of taking out private health insurance.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment Services. The minister has previously reported to the House that he is undertaking a round of consultations with the Job Network members around the country. Can the minister inform the House of what work is being done by the Job Network members in helping the unemployed into jobs?

—I would like to thank the member for Robertson for his question. The member for Robertson takes a great interest in the Job Network, and last Friday he opened a new office of Wesley Employment in his electorate. Over the past few weeks, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Rela tions and Small Business and I, singly or together, have consulted with a representative sample of 26 Job Network members. There have been three meetings with senior officers of Centrelink and two lengthy discussions with the board of the National Employment Services Association. Obviously, we would not be making this effort if everything was absolutely perfect, but I can inform the House that the Job Network is already significantly outperforming the Commonwealth Employment Service at getting unemployed people into work—and that is the test which really counts. The other day the well-known journalist Michael Duffy said:

answer.para: Many of the employment and training organisations in . . . the Job Network are non-profit groups (e.g. the Salvation Army, the Catholic Church) and admirable in the work they're doing. It makes a lot of sense for government to continue to work with such groups in a spirit of partnership.

Through these consultations it has been impossible not to feel a surge of pride and satisfaction at the work these great organisations are doing to help Australians in need, people like Adrian Atkinson—I quote from a document put out by the Salvation Army—who said:

I would like to thank you all for your help, support and encouragement while looking for work. Since working with a Salvation Army case manager, I have become more confident with job skills and am always encouraging others to use your services.
Frank Ross said of the Salvation Army Employment Plus:
You have been very helpful, honest, very open.
They've actually sent you for a job, not just taking your name. They cared about you.

There is no great secret to the success of these organisations. Whether their primary motivation is profit, service to the community or religious idealism, these great organisations are determined not just to work with the unemployed, but to put the unemployed into work.

The member for Werriwa understands the importance of harnessing the community sector to important social goals. The member for Werriwa is not shirking the task of policy creation. If the Leader of the Opposition were serious about intellectual renewal, he would immediately invite the member for Werriwa to return to Labor's front bench. The member for Werriwa's absence is a sign of the intellectual vacuum at the heart of a party which once prided itself on its mastery of ideas. But the member for Werriwa is not the only one—

talk.start.para: —I hope the minister is now returning to the question.
—I am indeed, Mr Speaker.
—I invite the minister to continue, but his reference to the member for Werriwa wasn't immediately relevant.

—I am now quoting Professor John Freeland, the head of the Evatt Foundation. John Freeland talks about the very things which underpin the Job Network. He talks of `the need to identify new policies relating to the generation of wealth, capturing the ingenuity, the creativity, the wealth generating capacity of the market, but harnessing that to achieve the sorts of social objectives we want'. That is a very good description of the Job Network. The Job Network precisely involves these sorts of principles. The Job Network is the so-called `third way' in action. What we have done with the Job Network is recruit a rollcall of the greatest names in Australian charity—Mission Australia, the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the Salvation Army and Centrecare, and through the Job Network we have enabled them to work even better with the Australians who need it most.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will recollect that he put his previous rebate to study by the Productivity Commission for its value in terms of producing savings in public health policy. Are you aware that page 88 of your own Productivity Commission found that spending $500 million a year to achieve a 3.7 per cent increase wasted $320 million? How can you now argue that spending $1.5 billion a year to achieve an increase of only 2.7 per cent is good public policy?
—In answer to the Leader of the Opposition, I have long since learnt at this dispatch box never to take at face value quotations that are made in public documents by—
—It is your report.
—Order!
—Mr Speaker—
—There is not a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—The Leader of the Opposition now has the call.
—I seek leave to table the document so the prime minister can attest as to whether or not it is accurate.
—Leave granted.
—Granting leave is not the prerogative of the Speaker and the Speaker doesn't intend to have documents tabled in the middle of the answer to a question. The Prime Minister has the call.

—I have learnt not to accept the interpretations placed on public documents by members of the opposition. But let me simply restate the choice. In the end this is about a choice: whether you believe in having a viable private health system or not. We do, you don't. That's the simple choice. For 13 years you allowed the private hospital system to waste away. For 13 years you rejected the entreaties even of those on your side of politics who wanted to preserve the private health system. Let me say to the Australian public that you are seeing played out in the parliament of Australia this week a perfect contrast—
—Mr Speaker, I go to the point of relevance. Did he see the Productivity Commission report when he proposed spending $1.5 billion? That is what the question was about, the Productivity Commission—
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Prime Minister has the call.

—The Australian people are seeing played out in the parliament this week a very clear demonstration that for middle Australia there is only one side of politics to support on private health insurance, and that is the coalition side. It is only the coalition that is prepared to say to middle Australian families: `We will give you financial help to take out private health insurance.' I say to all of those newly appointed Labor members who hold very small majorities: you go and talk to the families in your electorates about whether they want a private health insurance rebate. You go and ask the people who are battling to bring up a family on a modest middle income whether they want private health insurance and you will find that it is the overwhelming aspiration of middle Australian families to have private health insurance. They overwhelmingly welcome this initiative of the government. They know who is in there batting for them. It is not the Australian Labor Party; it is the coalition.

—This question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Can the minister inform the House how local veterans in my electorate of Barker will benefit from Monday's announcement of expanded veterans services in the Murray Mallee region?

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Barker for his first question in this House and also acknowledge that he is very keen to see the services in rural Australia improve. He knows, as we on this side of the parliament know, that it is this side of the House that is going to deliver better services to rural and regional Australia. The new member for Barker particularly has a great interest in our veteran community.

answer.para: I announced on Monday that the Department of Veterans' Affairs will be contracting local organisations in the Murray and Mallee regional electorates and also in the upper and mid-north part of South Australia in the electorate of Grey to assist in the provision of services to local veterans. These local organisations—the Murray Mallee Financial Information Service and the Upper and Mid North Rural Justice Committee—will provide weekly and fortnightly services to those two communities. They will be able not only to provide these services but also to explain eligibility to veterans in those communities and to take applications for compensation, health and income support entitlements.

This is in recognition of the fact that one-third of our nation's veterans live in rural Australia, and they deserve the same type of assistance and access to information as our veterans who live in the more populated parts of our nation. It is we on this side of the House, as I said earlier, who are going to deliver to these communities in rural and remote Australia, because we have at heart the interests of our veterans—wherever they live.

This bill is on our commitment to extend the eligibility of our veterans to the gold card. On 1 January next year, up to 50,000 veterans who have qualifying service from the Second World War will receive that eligibility. I am pleased to receive this question from the member for Barker. I look forward to working with him to bring better services to veterans in rural Australia and, particularly in this case, to veterans in the seat of Barker.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Has the minister's attention been drawn to comments by Major General John Hartley and senior officers of Navy's Maritime Headquarters Australia concerning chaos, fluctuating morale and job insecurity in Australia's Defence Force? Is the minister aware that during 1997-98, 80 lieutenant colonels, 42 colonels, 10 brigadiers and five major generals quit, and that an additional 20 per cent of the Army's lieutenant colonels are proposing to resign as a direct result of poor morale, lack of career paths and your government's ill-conceived cost cutting measures? What action do you propose to take to address this untenable situation?

—I am glad the member for Cunningham raised this matter, because it has been canvassed in a number of newspapers in Australia. The reaction is to the Defence Review Program which has been implemented across the whole of defence in Australia. At this stage we should draw to the attention of the House that the purpose of the reform program was to divert the balance within the Defence Force of Australia to 60 per cent active and 40 per cent support. As a consequence of those changes there will be shifts in personnel. It is the management of the shifts in personnel which is most important to the government. As a consequence of that I have asked the department—

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Members on the opposition front bench, the minister has the call.

—I have asked the Department of Defence to assess the implications of the changes in personnel and to press on at the same time with the reform program. It is utterly important to Australian defence that the $1 billion that we are saving in this defence reform be transferred to the active side of the defence portfolio. As a consequence of that, Australian defence forces in the future will be very much more on the alert than they have been in the past.
—When will you be on the alert? What are you going to do about the problem?

—Order! The minister will resume his seat. It has been a mystery to me just what it is that the seat of the member for the Northern Territory has in it that means that both its previous and present occupants have found it necessary to be perpetual interjectors. It could be interjection by osmosis, but I do not intend to sit here and tolerate further unnecessary interjections from the member for the Northern Territory. The minister has the call.

—As I was saying, the objective of the defence reform was to catch up on the 15 years in which the Labor Party neglected the defence forces. As a consequence of that, the Defence Reform Program will continue. The initiatives taken by the government are very welcome by the senior areas of defence.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. A number of newsagents and sub-agents in my electorate of Longman are concerned about the Australian Competition Tribunal's decision concerning the newsagency industry. Can the minister inform the House of the progress in discussions that have taken place with the key stakeholders in this matter?
—I thank the member for Longman for his question. I know he has a very keen interest in this issue, as do a number of my colleagues.
—So does the Prime Minister!

—And the Prime Minister does as well; I should never neglect the Prime Minister. I have had initial consultations with the key stakeholders in this industry. I have spoken with the publishers and representatives of the publishers. I have spoken with the umbrella organisations from newsagents and also with representatives of the sub-agents and a number of other stakeholders.

answer.para: I have asked the ACCC to conduct a mediation role in relation to this matter. It is essentially a private sector matter, but we have a very strong commitment to the protection of home delivery services. That commitment, given by the Prime Minister in the lead-up to the 1996 campaign and in the lead-up to the last campaign, is unchanged. We retain that commitment. I have asked the ACCC to conduct further consultations with the stakeholders. I have asked them to report back to me by 15 February so that we can pursue some issues and some solutions to parts of the problems that have arisen as a result of the tribunal's decision.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, there having been 20 questions, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—There are a number of people on the opposition benches who have specifically come to me seeking the call at the conclusion of question time. There are members who wish to ask questions of me. Among those with questions to me was the member for Hunter.
—Mr Speaker, I do want to ask a question of you, but I would first seek to make a personal explanation.
—For the sake of convenience, I will allow the member to proceed. Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I certainly do, Mr Speaker.
—Please proceed.

—During question time today, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business twisted what I had to say on the Small Business program to give the impression that I was in favour of his draconian, unfair dismissals legislation.

speech.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —My wife's employees, like 93 per cent of those who work in small business, work under state awards. The point I was trying to make is that the minister for small business is trying to give the small business community the impression that it is going to benefit from his unfair dismissal laws when in fact—
—Order! The member for Hunter will resume his seat. If he seeks indulgence, he is going the right way to ensure that it will not be granted.
—The member for Hunter has the call.

—In the last parliament, I wrote to Speaker Halverson asking him whether he was prepared to investigate the continual practice of ministers twisting or taking out of context comments by members on this side. I ask you, Mr Speaker, in order to uphold the standards—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is that the honourable member firstly abused the processes of the House in respect of a personal explanation because he did not demonstrate where he had been misrepresented. Now he abuses the indulgence you give by attempting to raise the matter simply under the guise of a question. The quote that was used during question time was a fair quote from the transcript and that ought to be the end of the matter.

—The Leader of the House has made his point. The member for Hunter has the call. I am prepared to allow the member for Hunter to proceed; I am presuming the question he is going to ask me, but it is not fair for me to make that presumption.
—My question to you is put in the spirit of upholding the standards in this place and, in that sense, is rather apolitical.
—I have gleaned the question.

—Mr Speaker, I ask you whether you would be prepared to investigate this constant misuse of the parliament and report back to the parliament as to how you in some way might be able to address that abuse.

—I am happy to respond immediately to the question from the member for Hunter. I have sat in this parliament along with a number of other members for 16 years. I have not, in that time, noticed any particular change in the way in which ministers represent members of the opposition.

—Mr Speaker, I have a couple of questions to you. As I understand it, two MPIs, matters of public importance, were submitted to you today for determination under the terms of the standing orders. My concern that has been raised with you is that, as I understand it, and I would seek your guidance in respect of this matter, an MPI has to be lodged with the Speaker before noon. The MPI that was selected—which was not the one submitted by me dealing with difficulties in Australia's defence forces in respect of personnel and other matters—was subsequently circulated in this chamber whilst debate was still under way on the matter of the MPI which was being canvassed by the honourable member for Boothby.

question.para: My question is also prompted by the fact that the third reading of that legislation still has not been moved in this place and subsequently will not be until later. Therefore, I am asking whether it is appropriate in all the circumstances for us to deal with the MPI of the honourable member for Boothby which deals with an opposition matter rather than a government matter when page 532 of House of Representatives Practice clearly says that `the principal function of the modern House is to monitor and publicise the actions and administration of the executive government'—not the opposition but the executive government. I ask you, therefore, whether you have been satisfied, as you are entitled to be, that the most urgent and important issue has been selected, given that over 40 of Australia's senior Defence Force personnel are meeting today to discuss the matter.

talk.start.para: —The member for Cunningham will resume his seat. He has made his point.
—I have another question following from that, Mr Speaker.

—Let me respond to the member for Cunningham by indicating that the first question I asked the Clerk when the two MPIs were submitted to me was that they were both submitted on time, as indeed they were. When the MPI is read to the House later this day, I believe that any fair-minded person in this chamber will deduce that the MPI that has been selected is the one that is of the most urgent and pressing in parliamentary terms.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am on my feet and I have not finished what I am saying.
—We don't accept what you are saying.
—Would the member for Lyons care simply to indicate that he regrets making that sort of interjection?
—I do, Mr Speaker.
—Furthermore, it seems that Speaker Child ruled—and I checked this—that it was appropriate that the anticipation rule not apply to MPIs. It was on those grounds that I made that ruling.

—Mr Speaker, in respect of the answer you have just given, as I understand it, the fact from House of Representatives Practice is that the matter of the subject of the member for Boothby's MPI has been gagged. He has spoken in this place. What more could he say on the issue in an MPI when he could have had the opportunity to talk on the bills?

—The member for Cunningham knows better than he does. The member for Cunningham will not refer again to the matter on which I have ruled. I called him because he said he had an additional question to me.
—Can I have another question then, Mr Speaker?

—Let this be clearly understood. When the member for Cunningham raised his initial question to me I responded to it. I consider the matter dealt with. If he has any other unrelated matter to raise, I will hear him.
—It is another related matter.
—I want it unrelated to the MPI.
—It is related to the selection of the MPI.
—I have dealt with the MPI as it applies today. If there is a further matter on MPIs to be dealt with, I will entertain that with the member for Cunningham later this day in my office.
—It is an important matter for all members of parliament so that other members know what they can do in future.
—If I deem it to be a matter that needs wider debate or discussion, I will bring it to the attention of parliament prior to question time tomorrow.

—Mr Speaker, when you considered the matter at 12 o'clock the debate was still under way at that point of time. As I think all of us would accept, you are not a prophet and you would not have known that the start of the gag process would have taken place half an hour later. It was a current debate at the time you did it. When choosing between the two—the defence issue with the large number of resignations and the MPI matter, which was thoroughly capable of being canvassed within the debate on the bill—did you consider in making a judgment the possibility that the opportunity was there for members to make the very important points they no doubt wish to make on the health legislation before them and select instead as a matter of public importance the defence needs of this nation?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. House of Representatives Practice makes it very clear that a Speaker is not required, nor is there any obligation whatsoever on a Speaker, to provide reasons. Furthermore, it has long been the practice with former Speakers, including the member for Cunningham, that they would not give reasons. On that basis, my point of order is that it is inappropriate for the Leader of the Opposition to ask that question. In the interests of maintaining the longstanding practice—practice for 13 years when Labor was in office—that question should not be answered.

—The Leader of the House has, in fact, made a perfectly proper point of order, but I had deemed that it was appropriate to allow the Leader of the Opposition, given the additional latitude extended to both the Leader of the Opposition and the Prime Minister, to ask a question that I had considered closed. For that reason, I stand by my ruling to the member for Cunningham that I am happy to meet with him in my office to discuss any further matters of public importance matters. I will go to bed tonight with a totally clear conscience over the selection of the MPI. Does the member for Cunningham have a totally unrelated matter to matters of public importance?
—Are you giving me the call?
—No, I am not, not unless this is a matter unrelated to—
—Am I getting the call?
—I am not being difficult with the member for Cunningham. I was endeavouring to work my way through those people who had sought to ask questions of the Speaker before going to other resolutions.
—Mr Speaker, I stood to seek the call. I was the only one who did. Therefore, I assume I have the call.
—No, I think it is reasonable to me to observe that your colleagues were anticipating that you were seeking the call on an unrelated matter.
—No, it is related. Quite clearly it is related.

—I am sorry. I am saying that if you are not asking me a question and not seeking to make a personal explanation I require you to resume your seat, and I will call you when your other colleagues have asked me questions they wish to ask me or when I have dealt with their personal explanations.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—Mr Speaker, I would think that is a proposition which is not sustained. In fact, I would refer to the comments that the Prime Minister made about me when I was doing the job; he thought I did a great job, thank you.
—If on vacating this chair the worst misrepresentation I face is the misrepresentation you have just alleged you faced, I will be a very happy man.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—In question time today, the Treasurer imputed that I had attempted to prevent the Commissioner of Taxation from clamping down on tax evasion. That is not the case, and the Treasurer has grossly misrepresented my correspondence to him.

subdebateinfo.title: Electronic Transmissions to the Table Office

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I have a question for you. Like a lot of members, I want to put some questions on the Notice Paper . Of course, as you know, we have an email system and can very easily transmit questions from our office to the Table Office and assist the productivity of the individual who has to check and prepare those questions—but, of course, that is strictly prohibited. Mr Speaker, would you consider allowing members of parliament to email questions to the Table Office, even at the risk of bringing the parliament up to date with technology?

—I think the latter part of the comment was hardly fair, given the level of technological facility that we enjoy. I will discuss the matter with the Table Office and get back to the member for Chifley.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—During question time, the Treasurer referred to me by name, and to a letter I sent to him on 15 June this year on behalf of a constituent. He then misrepresented my actions on behalf of my constituent by stating that I was complaining about the Taxation Commissioner.

speech.para: My letter to the Treasurer consisted of three brief sentences. The first and second sentences identify the constituent and the matter on which a response from the Treasurer was sought. The third sentence merely requested a response. How anyone of integrity could draw the conclusion that he did is beyond the pale.

talk.start.para: —The member for Port Adelaide has indicated where he was misrepresented and will resume his seat.
—He is a lying sod.
—Why don't you sue him, Pete? Sue him!

—The member for Port Adelaide has been here almost as long as I have. He knows that that personal explanation finished in a most unprofessional way, and I require him to withdraw the statement he made about the Treasurer.
—I withdraw; he told a gross untruth.
—The member for Port Adelaide will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—Mr Speaker, in answering a question from the Leader of the Opposition today, the Treasurer stated that I had written to him on 22 June and implied that I was supporting tax avoidance or minimisation. This is simply not true.

speech.para: I received a letter from a constituent concerning a complex taxation matter. I forwarded the letter to the Treasurer without comment but asking for the Treasurer's response to my constituent's concerns. Any member would have done exactly the same, and I am happy to table the correspondence regarding this.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—Mr Speaker, during question time, in my absence, the Treasurer misled the House—and comments made to me drew that to my attention. I arranged for a transcript of what the Treasurer said when misleading the House in relation to me, and it is in the following terms:

speech.para: I am aware that he is taking action—
and this was in answer to a question from the Leader of the Opposition—
because I have had numbers of complaints from members of parliament that he is taking too aggressive an action.
He then named the member for Fremantle and, in relation to me, said:
. . . a complaint from Daryl Melham, the member for Banks, on 11 June 1998 about the action that the commissioner was taking.
I note the word `complaint'. Then later in the answer, the transcript goes on to read:
. . . and his backbenchers are running around saying, `Stop them, please!'
In relation to me, Mr Speaker, the misleading of the House occurs in that the letter I sent to the Treasurer on 11 June is a short letter—

talk.start.para: —I am sorry and I interrupt the member for Banks reluctantly, but I presume that he is concerned about a personal misrepresentation.
—That is right. The personal misrepresentation is `a complaint from Daryl Melham, the member for Banks', the inference being that I personally was complaining to the Treasurer.

—The member for Banks has the call and may proceed. But I need to point out to him that what he is defending is a personal misrepresentation, not in fact the misleading of the House, which is the allegation he made a few moments earlier.
—He has. He has misled the House.
—The misleading is in stating that I made a complaint. I did not make a complaint. There were representations on behalf of the constituent.
—Yes, I understand. But the facility allows you to indicate where you have been personally misrepresented. That is all I was pointing out.
—Yes. I will delete his name, and I had better read it in full so that it cannot be said that I have cut and pasted it.
—No, I will table it.
—No.
—The member for Banks has the call through me.
—Mr Speaker, I do seek your indulgence, and I do have a question to you because it goes to the very heart of protection of constituents and privacy. So there are a number of matters.
—The member for Banks has been personally misrepresented. We will then move to a question.
—The letter reads:

speech.para: Dear Treasurer,
I write on behalf of Mr . . . concerning the treatment of Bud Plan Business Project by the Taxation Commissioner. Mr—
and I delete the name—

wrote on 2 June 1998 expressing concern that the Taxation Commissioner intends to announce in the press that participants in the Bud Plan Business Project are willing participants in a tax avoidance scheme. Mr . . . states that he is a genuine investor and he is concerned that he was not allowed to be informed privately of the commissioner's grounds for his allegations of tax avoidance.

This is the relevant part; it is relevant because, in the hubbub, it is innocent people who get named in the parliament—and that is a classic example of why the tactics of this Treasurer are wrong. The letter continues:
I am enclosing a copy of his letter and would appreciate your considered response.
Government members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Members on my right! The member for Banks has the call. I would ask him to come quickly to the point at which he has been personally misrepresented.
—I will, Mr Speaker. This is in relation to my representations. It states:

speech.para: I am enclosing a copy of his letter and would appreciate your considered response.
I look forward to hearing from you at your earliest convenience with regard to this matter.
Yours sincerely . . .
Mr Speaker, at no stage did I complain to the Treasurer. In terms of indulgence, Mr Speaker, I do seek your indulgence and I do have a question for you.

talk.start.para: —We have now finished with the personal explanation, and you are now seeking indulgence.

—Yes, I am seeking your indulgence to raise this matter and the treatment by the Treasurer of correspondence by me to him. In my personal explanation I did inadvertently name the constituent. That goes to the heart of the matter. The Treasurer wanted to table the letter.
—He wanted to table it.
—He wanted to table it. That is the point. That is why I seek your indulgence and ask the question.

—The member for Banks has indicated where he was misrepresented. The House understands his concern, and I believe he has offered an explanation for it. I do not believe it is reasonable to imply that the Treasurer in any way involved your constituent in this exercise. He did not, after all, name your constituent. You have indicated where you were offended, and you have had an opportunity to explain that. I do not see any reason to grant indulgence to proceed further. If you have a particular concern, I will hear you out and then rule on the indulgence.

—Mr Speaker, my particular concern—and, again, the Treasurer offered the member for Barton the opportunity to publish the letter through the gallery—is that it was an attempt to attack me through representations in terms of a constituent. That is why I claimed I was misrepresented. What I am concerned about is this practice continuing. It occurred in the last parliament when the foreign minister released the itinerary of a shadow minister, Mr Crean. I am concerned that, if this practice is allowed to continue by you, Mr Speaker, then the only representations we on this side of the House can make to ministers is to forward correspondence from clients with `With Compliments' slips. I am concerned about the practice in relation to correspondence between me and the minister being misused in this House.

—The member for Banks will resume his seat. He has made his point. He has indicated where he has been personally misrepresented. He has had an opportunity to make that point to the House. I do not believe that any action taken by the Treasurer could be deemed to have been improper in the context of question time.
—Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence.
—Indulgence is granted to the Leader of the Opposition, but I do not intend to extend indulgence to all of the opposition members who were mentioned by the Treasurer.

—Thank you for your indulgence, Mr Speaker. There have been occasions in this House from time to time on both sides for ministers answering questions to raise the fact that they have received representations. I have never, however, in this place heard it done so extensively and in such detail in relation to private correspondence by constituents or so misleadingly in the way in which it was handled. Now that we have heard the content of those particular letters, in no way, shape or form do they justify for one minute the interpretation and exaggeration the Treasurer sought to place upon them.
—Oh, grow up.
—I have indulgence at the moment, thank you very much. You get on your scrapers in question time and rabbit on all the time. Now you are getting a bit of your own back. Sit down!

—The Leader of the Opposition must know that he is exceeding the indulgence any chair would grant with those comments. I have ruled on this exercise. I have ruled that all of those members who felt they had been misrepresented had an opportunity to make the point and that the Treasurer has acted consistent with actions that I have witnessed here in the time I have been in the parliament.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.

—In question time the Leader of the Opposition alleged that the government was being soft on a particular tax avoidance plan. That was his question. If he asks that question and the particular plan in question has been the subject of complaint to me by Labor Party members, I will disclose it.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has the same obligation as everybody else to move to the point at which he was personally misrepresented. Before he rises, I would make the point to members on my left—and it is conspicuously obvious—that the Treasurer could scarcely be heard, not even by the chair, above the hubbub on my left. The Treasurer is entitled to a personal explanation.

—Mr Speaker, in accordance with practice in this House, if I have had representations on behalf of constituents from Labor Party members suggesting not that the government was soft on tax avoidance but that it was being too hard, I will disclose that. The second point I make is that I disclosed no names. The third point I make is this: I disclosed only a few of the Labor members that have written to me. I have a lot longer list.
—I am very grateful to the Treasurer that he did not go through the rest of the list, because we might have been here for the rest of the afternoon. The matter is closed.

—I have a question for you, Mr Speaker. During question time, the Treasurer said in reply to the matters raised by the member for Port Adelaide that he would circulate the letter to the gallery. I heard him make that comment.
—I did not.
—I am saying very clearly that I heard him make that comment and I am asking you, as the Speaker—
—The member will resume his seat. The Treasurer has indicated he did not make the comment.

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Once again, the Speaker has not been able to complete a statement due to interjections from both the right and the left, including from the member for Batman.
—Speak up! What about him?
—I have already indicated, while you were so busy interjecting, a comment or two to those on my right.
—You responded to the Treasurer.

—This matter is now closed. I hear what the member for Brisbane said. The least I can do is check the Hansard and ensure that, as the Treasurer has indicated, he did not make that statement and, if he did, require him not to proceed with that action.

—Mr Speaker, I will tell you now, I do not intend to disclose anybody's name. I did not in question time and I will not do it. The only person who disclosed any constituent's name was the member for Banks.
—The Treasurer will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member for Hunter claim to have been misrepresented?
—I certainly do, Mr Speaker.
—Please proceed.
—Mr Speaker, during question time today, the Treasurer misrepresented me in the same matter raised by the member for Banks and those before him.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave of the House to have deleted from the Hansard the name that I inadvertently referred to in my personal explanation.
—That's censorship.
—It is not censorship. It is doing the right thing. I made a mistake and I will own up to it, unlike others.
—If the granting of leave is in the hands of the Speaker, and I understand it is, I will look at the matter and report back to the House.

—Mr Speaker, in light of the debate today, could I ask you to investigate the status of correspondence to members of parliament and to report, in particular, whether it is the subject of privilege. I appreciate that that cannot be done today, but it is a matter which I think should be appropriately investigated.

—This matter has been blown out of all reasonable proportion. I do not intend to pursue it any further other than the assurance that I have already given to the member for Banks. The matter is closed.
—Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and Hansard .
