talk.start.para: —I present the Auditor-General's audit report No. 17 for 1998-99 entitled Performance audit—Acquisition of Aerospace Simulators—Department of Defence .

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —I have received letters from the honourable member for Cunningham and the honourable member for Boothby proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by standing order 107, I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important—that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Boothby, namely:

speech.para: The opposition's failure to recognise the threat posed to Australia's health system if private health insurance is put on the back burner.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Mr Speaker, for your wise choice. I often meet from time to time with Dr Jim Forbes, who was the Minister for Health under the Holt and Gorton ministries. Reflecting on earlier times, he said that, while he was the Minister for Health, he often used to discuss different health proposals with the cabinet of the time. He always said that it was very hard to attract interest, that people's eyes would glaze over when he discussed health because there were much bigger issues going on—Australia was fighting the Vietnam War and there were Australian troops throughout South-East Asia, which reflects a different focus that politics had 30 years ago.

speech.para: But, in 1998, as important as we see defence issues, no-one would argue that health is one of the major issues and one of the major determinants of electoral opinion. For as long as I can remember, it has always been in the top three. Now more recent surveys show that it is in the top one or top two. By way of declaring a personal interest, I myself have private health insurance and believe that people on my sort of income should have private health insurance.

By way of declaring a personal interest, I have to say that I, unlike most of the members of the ALP, actually worked in the public hospital system. Members of the ALP come in here and talk about Medicare and the public hospital system as if they have a mortgage on them. The difference between the Liberal and National parties and the ALP is that we believe in both systems. We believe in a public hospital system side by side with a strong private hospital system.

Members of the ALP represent only two-thirds of the health system. They do not represent the private health system, they do not represent people with private health insurance and they have an ideological opposition to those with private health insurance. The ALP needs some balance. They need to look at a stable and sustainable health system—and that includes both the private and public health systems.

I began work in the public hospital system. I worked until the 1996 election in the public hospital system. I would have liked to have continued to work in Casualty in my local hospital, but unfortunately, not wishing to fall foul of the provisions of section 44 of the constitution in holding office of profit under the Crown, I had to resign when the election was called.

The private system plays a critical role in taking pressure off the public system. It provides half the operations, one-third of the admissions and a quarter of the bed days. That is the sector in health that the opposition do not represent. It has been estimated by Access Economics that a two per cent drop in private health insurance costs the public system the equivalent of 325,000 hospital bed days. That is the equivalent of two major teaching hospitals running all year round. Now under the Medicare agreements a one per cent drop in private health insurance means that we are obliged to give the states and territories an extra $83 million. What that means is that, if the drop-out continues at the present rate, we will have to pay the states and territories $500 million a year by the year 2000. Medicare was always designed to work side by side with a strong private system.

We need to look at the major reason why private health insurance levels are dropping. The major reason is rising premiums. Premiums are rising almost 3½ times faster than inflation. Before 1990 there were a number of decisions that the previous Labor government took which directly contributed something like 39 per cent to the cost of premiums now. There was a 40 per cent explosion in premiums between 1986 and 1988 and there were four government decisions that were taken. They were the removal of the bed day subsidy, the removal of the reinsurance pool, the reduction of the Medicare rebate for in-patients from 85 per cent to 75 per cent; and then later the Medicare agreements, which encouraged public patients to be pushed through public hospitals.

Since September 1996, the government has said that premium rises will occur only if it is due to solvency requirements. Some requests from funds to raise the premiums have been rejected by the committee consisting of the Treasurer, the Minister for Health and Aged Care and the Prime Minister. Premiums probably will rise—there are the costs of technology and the process of adverse selection which is adding to premium rises—but having a 30 per cent rebate of the cost of your premium is much better than the incentives scheme because the incentives scheme is fixed. If the premiums rise, the rebate will be 30 per cent of whatever the premium is.
Some people have suggested that the private health sector is somehow inefficient. The Industry Commission commented:

The rapid growth in premiums has been interpreted by some as showing that the private system is either increasingly inefficient or anti-competitive or both. But the facts are inconvenient to such an interpretation.

The Industry Commission, the Productivity Commission, rejected that assertion which we have heard continuously from Labor members in this debate. In fact, they said that there is competition between the funds and the main reason that the premiums are rising is that the payouts are rising.

The Institute of Actuaries of Australia said that the health system is inherently unstable. What you have is a process of adverse selection. As the premiums rise, young fit and healthy people drop out. That means that there are more people in the fund more likely to make a claim and so the premiums rise, and that is going on as a circle. The government's rebate attempts to address that by making premiums 30 per cent cheaper.

To say that the funds are inefficient is wrong. The health funds already try to discourage overuse through step-down contracts with the hospitals which reduce the payments after several treatments, co-payments and benefit ceilings. We believe that reducing the premiums by 30 per cent will help people stay in private health insurance and will also encourage people back.

The 30 per cent rebate is the equivalent of the support that existed before Labor was elected in 1983. There were always levels of subsidy for private health insurance. What we are doing is restoring the level of support that was there when Medicare was introduced in 1984. It also allows time for the government's reforms in private health insurance to have effect. We have not heard much about them from the opposition. We are allowing the funds to offer loyalty bonuses and group discounts for groups of employees. We are setting up a consumer information service to help people choose between the wide number of products. We are also encouraging simplified billing. That is very important. Sportsmed in South Australia is now offering people—with the agreement of all the health care providers—one bill. There is also no gap. They are looking at the problem of out-of-pocket expenses. The National Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists are encouraging no gap. The Melbourne Private Hospital has simplified billing and there is no gap. The government is trying to get more of these agreements for the out-of-pocket expenses and the simplified billing.

There are two million people in Australia with private health insurance on incomes below $30,000. There are 700,000 people on incomes below $20,000. The ALP try to say that private health insurance is just for affluent people. That is not true. In fact, they are not even representing their own electorates. In each of their own electorates there are, on average, 39,000 voters who hold private health insurance.
Mr Cadman interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I will get to that in a second. The rebate is available as a tax rebate, as a cheaper premium or it is available from a Medicare office or can be paid directly into your bank account. The rebate will be equivalent to or better than a tax deduction for everyone on incomes below $50,000 after we have our new tax scales in place from 1 July 2000. Tony Quinn and Associates estimate that a 25 to 30 per cent reduction in price is needed to bring people back into private health insurance.

speech.para: We need to address some of the untruths that are being told by the Labor Party in this debate. The Labor Party needs to stand on its record. First of all, it has said that this measure redirects funds away from public hospitals. That is wrong. The government is spending $32 billion over five years, which is a 17.6 per cent real increase. When Jenny Macklin, the member for Jagajaga, was chairing the National Health Strategy, in the 1991 report, Hospital Services in Australia, she recognised that just pouring more money into public hospitals was likely to make things worse. She said:

. . . increased funding to public hospitals is also likely to lead to a change in the equilibrium between public hospitals, private hospitals and private health insurance, without necessarily achieving the level of impact intended. If increased funding to public hospitals reduces the perceived pressure on public hospitals through smaller waiting lists and shorter waiting times, it is likely that private health insurance levels will drop. This could result in increased demand for public hospitals and reduced revenue from private patients. The result may be a return to the situation which existed prior to the provision of extra resources.

The Labor Party have said that this measure does nothing to increase the efficiency of the funds. There is already competition between the funds. I have already addressed that. They say it is poorly targeted. Medicare is not targeted. There is no income test or assets test for Medicare. You say that it is all right for a millionaire to get bulk-billed and it is all right for a millionaire to go to a public hospital, but you object to two million people on incomes below $30,000 getting the 30 per cent rebate for private health insurance.

The Labor Party also do not recognise that the people who have dropped their private health insurance are the ones on the top 60 per cent of incomes. They are the ones that are wanted back because, when they are in the public system, they have influence and wealth and they push the less affluent out of the way. Labor also think we are not addressing multiple bills and out-of-pocket costs. Well, we are. They say it will not increase the proportion of people privately insured. I hope it will. So that is the Labor Party.

We need to ask: what is the natural conclusion of all of this? What is the Labor Party's vision for the health system in Australia? They used to come in in the last parliament and criticise the private health insurance incentives scheme, then they adopted it as their policy. The Labor Party are not concerned with the level of private health insurance being 30 per cent. They probably think it should be lower. The Labor vision for the Australian health system is to have a small private sector—probably 10 per cent or 15 per cent—and everyone else in Medicare. That is the Labor vision. And if it is not, they should tell us why it is not and why they do not support the rebate and why they do not support increasing the level of assistance to where it was before Medicare was introduced.

That is a two-tier system. It is Labor Party policy to introduce a two-tier system into Australia. If you want to know what that looks like, go to the UK, go to the National Health Service. There will always be people privately insured but it will be only the elite. We need to look at Labor's record. When they came to power in 1983, 65 per cent of people were privately insured. In 1984, when Medicare was introduced, 50 per cent were privately insured. When they left office, it was just over 30 per cent. Morgan Research has shown that 67 per cent of people want the 30 per cent rebate.

I believe the opposition are very short-sighted on this. They are not representing their constituents. They are representing only those constituents who do not have private health insurance. We represent them all. It is worth going through the electorates of Labor Party people to see the number of people holding private health insurance. The Leader of the Opposition has 45,820 voters with private health insurance in his electorate. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has 32,424 voters with private health insurance in his electorate. The member for Jagajaga, the ALP spokeswoman for health, has 36,719 voters with private health insurance in her electorate.

I see the member for Paterson is sitting at the table. I hope he will be contributing to this debate because the member for Paterson won his seat by 936 votes at the last election. If 936 people change their vote, you are out. There are 41,764 voters in Paterson with private health insurance. The member for Paterson knows what this means because he has had it before. In 1993-96 he was in this parliament and he voted for all of Labor's indirect tax rises without any compensation and in 1996 he stood on his record, he saw the ads about his voting record and what happened? He lost.

The member for Paterson needs to stand on his voting record at the next election. This is about the fifth sitting day. It is the second week. We have had the first division and already the member for Paterson has clocked up a vote where he has disenfranchised 41,764 voters in his electorate. I will go through some of the seats: Bass has 24,692 voters with private health insurance; Dickson, 30,000; Kingston, 38,000; McMillan, 23,000; Northern Territory, 34,000; Stirling, 58,000; Chisholm, 39,000; Griffith, 33,000; and Swan, 54,000. All of those people need only 2,000 or fewer votes to change and they are out.

The Labor Party think this is like 1969. Kim Beazley is like Gough Whitlam, and they are just going to keep on increasing it. For these people in the marginal seats it is more like 1984; you do not know what you stand for. You need to stand on your voting record and you need to clock up more votes like this, because you are not representing half of your electorate. Half of your electorate were disenfranchised by your vote today in the House of Representatives. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I do wish to participate in this MPI debate. Actually, I wanted to participate in the debate earlier but, unfortunately, the member for Boothby and his colleagues voted to gag the debate and prevent all those people on this side from talking about health and the provision of health services to the people in the electorate of Paterson and every other electorate who are now being forced to wait extraordinary amounts of time for things like cataract surgery so they can see, so they can read the paper and so they can drive their car and get to work. Or perhaps some of these people are wanting to have a hip replacement or a knee replacement so they can go about their everyday life and do their own shopping. Perhaps they are wanting some other minor type of surgery that is necessary.

speech.para: Maybe it is about the Commonwealth dental health program, from which the other side cut $92 million. That prevented people in my electorate having urgently needed dental health care that would have allowed them to eat ordinary foods rather than having to drink soup through a straw. But let us be quite clear what the government does stand for because no-one else, apart from them, understands their convoluted thinking.
Dr Southcott interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Boothby has had his turn.

—Thank you very much for supporting me, Mr Deputy Speaker. Let us just go through some of the history of this particular legislation. I would like to go back first to 1996. I know too well I was not here—I had a bit of time on the sideline—but I do particularly remember the Prime Minister's statement after 1996 that he wanted to lift the standard in this place.

speech.para: Well, the members of the government have had that opportunity today. As the member for Boothby correctly says, this is the first piece of legislation of this parliament where members of the government and members of the opposition could really get their teeth into an issue that people of Australia feel strongly about. I support one comment that the member for Boothby made, and that is that health is a very important issue to the people of Australia.

I would be quite happy for the member for Boothby and for the minister for health to come to the Paterson electorate at any time and meet those people who are now being denied urgent health services because of the waiting lists in the public hospitals and explain to those people just how this piece of legislation is going to shorten the waiting list for them, because they will not be able to do it. They will not be able to guarantee that $1 will be spent on public health as a result of this legislation that is going to cost the taxpayers of Australia $1½ billion.

What do we get from that? We get the answer that the Prime Minister gave today that, for the princely sum of $1½ billion, the coverage of people by private health insurance will go from 30.3 per cent to 33 per cent of the population. They will be covered by private health insurance as a result of this legislation that you have approved today. But what did you vote against? The shadow minister moved an amendment that you voted against. Let us have a look at what that amendment said:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for:
(1) increased funding for the public hospital system;

That makes it quite clear what the government stands for: they do not stand for increasing funding to the public health system. If you had supported that, you would have voted for it. It is all right for the member for Boothby now to say, `No, that is not what I meant,' but that is not the way he voted because that is on record and will be shown up. He voted to object to increased funding for the public health system. The amendment goes on:
(2) measures to promote efficiency in private hospitals and control costs;
So he voted against that too. He does not want those measures to be put in place. The third point in the amendment that was moved by the opposition reads:

(3) measures to make health insurance more attractive by providing private patients a single hospital bill and insurance to cover the cost of hospital and medical services so that patients don't face large out-of-pocket costs.

Many references have been made to my coming back here. I can assure all members who have represented an electorate and lost their seat that if they do want to get back here they should get around and talk to the people and find out what the issues are about. I like to think that one of the reasons I came back is that I knocked on tens of thousands of doors and I met lots of people.

I met lots of people who were not being serviced by the health system. What they could not understand was why the government in its first term promised something like $1.4 billion to solve this health fund scheme, yet the fees kept going up. Apart from paying more fees, what happened when they went to hospital? They had an operation and then they were slugged with the higher costs. What made it strange was that people who may be in the next bed, who may be operated on by exactly the same surgeon, who got exactly the same service and who were covered by Medicare did not have to pay those extra costs.

I know that the government hates Medicare. They attack Medicare at every opportunity. But one of the things that the member for Boothby has completely and conveniently overlooked is the fact that when you pay your Medicare levy it is not a flat rate, it is a percentage. So the more you earn, the more you pay. That is until you get to $100,000 when there is a one per cent surcharge.

And, like the member for Boothby, I will declare an interest. I have private health insurance too; I have always had it. You probably pay the surcharge—no, I don't think you do because you have private health insurance. Let us just look at the one per cent surcharge on an income of $100,000 where you can have a choice: you can have private health insurance and pay out maybe a couple of grand a year, or you can pay the $1,000 surcharge which is one per cent. If, on the other hand, you have an income of $200,000 then you can either pay the two grand surcharge or two grand private health insurance—you can get out of it. Anyone earning over that amount will obviously elect not to pay the surcharge and will take out health insurance—they save money.

What is this government going to do to those people? They are going to give them an automatic rebate. They are not going to improve health services for those in need, but they are certainly going to give a rebate to those high earners that are already working the system to their own advantage.

talk.start.para: —You are confused.

—I know I am confused. I am confused by the actions of people who have come out of the medical system, who have worked in public hospitals, who know the lack of services that exist there, who know the demand for the services and who are prepared to come in and support this piece of Hippocratic—it must have been a play on words; I know he has given the Hippocratic oath—this hypocritical piece of legislation.

speech.para: I would have thought that a Prime Minister and a government that talks about battlers and that is prepared to give service to the battlers would make sure that service is delivered to the battlers. But that is not what this piece of legislation is about. This piece of legislation is purely about looking after the wealthy. I am more than happy to go back to my electorate and tell the people there like me who have private health insurance, `No, I don't support giving people like me a rebate.' I support the battlers waiting for urgent surgery so that they can get on with their life but who are told, `Come back and see us in 12 months.' I have met people who have been waiting three or four years to get dental care. I suggest that the member for Boothby slip out and take an Aspro or some other form of medication. The point is that services are not being delivered now and the government cannot assist that.

I appreciate the fact that any speech we hear today is going to be politically motivated. So let us ignore the politics of it for a minute and go to someone who often writes in the columns and does not always support our side. As a matter of fact, I have heard him quoted quite often by the Prime Minister. Let us talk about Ross Gittins's column today in the Sydney Morning Herald. It identifies a number of the problems with the current legislation that we have been debating. He says:
The problem, as years of propaganda have schooled us to believe, is the ever-declining number of people with private insurance.

The Prime Minister has told us today that $1.5 billion will increase participation by 2.7 per cent. What do the states want? They want $750 million, which is half of what the government is proposing, to solve all the states' health problems. But this government is not even prepared to do that. Imagine all the people in Coffs Harbour lined up waiting to get into the hospital there. We could solve their problems with half the amount of money. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like you to join with me some time and look at the people in Maitland and Port Stephens who need health care. It has been denied, for half the amount of money that this government wants to spend.

But what is happening to the cost of fees? They are rising at three or four times the rate of inflation. That is part of the problem. The government is throwing this vast bucketful of money. Can members comprehend what $1.5 billion is? I cannot, and most Australians cannot. Between 1993 and 1996, Deputy Speaker Nehl and I canvassed very strongly for the Pacific Highway to be constructed in a proper fashion between Sydney and Bris bane to make it safe. That is about the sort of money that will do that. It is going to be spent over 10 years, though. We are talking about $1.5 billion each year over a 10-year period. We are talking about $15 billion. What can you do with $15 billion? If you only give the states half of that to solve their health problems, you have $7.5 billion to save. You can build five Pacific Highways from Sydney to Brisbane with that money, and those opposite claim that they are all about financial management. This is not financial management.

We are seeing one of the greatest bits of waste that this country has ever had presented to it by an irresponsible government. It is a government that does not know how to govern. It is a government that surprises me. When I came back here, I thought, `What is it going to be like to sit in opposition? What is it going to be like to have a government with its flag up giving us the policies?' All I have seen from this government is that it wants to attack the Labor Party. It is still talking about Paul Keating, Graham Richardson and Ros Kelly. But the ministers are sitting opposite. That is where the people who make the decisions reside. Can they make them? No, they cannot. They certainly cannot make the right ones. There has been no greater evidence than this piece of legislation.

Today will go down in history as a day when this government had the opportunity to support the ordinary people of Australia. It had the opportunity to spend money on a public health system to give service. It had the opportunity to give service to people who have private health insurance and to make sure that the bill reflected their needs. It failed. That is the shame of today. The member for Boothby, as I said, is more than welcome to come to Paterson with me. He can bring his ministerial mate. I would love to see him because I have thousands of people lined up who want to know why they cannot get the health service that their lifestyle urgently demands and which the government consistently refuses to give them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am more than happy to support my colleague the member for Boothby this afternoon in this very important MPI.
—If it's so important, why did you gag the debate?

—We did not gag the debate. We were willing to debate this subject. We debated some amendments. We did not gag the debate. What we are looking at here is the whole gambit of health. It seems to be something that is beyond the comprehension of those opposite. The member for Paterson said that he doorknocked tens of thousands of homes. If he doorknocked tens of thousands of homes, it would have been clear to him that about 70 per cent of the people in those homes, if we are to believe the Morgan Gallup poll, prefer a rebate system.

speech.para: The cost of health care in Australia is $42 billion. That includes the Commonwealth, the states, local government and the private sector. About $22 billion of that is the Commonwealth's charge. That is a mind-boggling figure by any standard.

When Labor came to power in 1983, 64 per cent of Australians had private health cover. When they went out in 1996, that was down to about 33 per cent. You do not have to be Einstein to work out that two-thirds of Australians were substantially looking after their own health care when Labor came to power and one-third were using the public system. At the end of that 13 years of Labor government, two-thirds of them were reliant on the public system and only a third on the private system. The dreadful feature of all of this is that for every one per cent of people who drop off private health insurance, as the member for Boothby said, the cost to the Commonwealth is $83 million.

I would like to return to the member for Paterson's proposition—the proposition put to the parliament last night by the Leader of the Opposition—that for about $720 million all the costs that the states are ever likely to need will be met. That was your charge, was it not?

talk.start.para: —Per annum, yes.

—Per annum. Let me put this to you: if eight per cent more people fall off private health insurance, you have im mediately gobbled that up. Eight times $83 million and it is gone. Where do you go them? You are feeding yet a bigger monster, so instead of having about 30 per cent of people privately insured, you would have about 22 per cent and your costs would be growing.

speech.para: It is interesting that you mentioned Ross Gittins, because he had some factual errors in that article today. For example, he inferred that the total cost of the scheme would be $1.8 billion—$1.2 billion a year on top of the $600 million a year for the existing scheme. Actually, the correct figure is $1.38 billion in the first year, of which $380 million is for the current scheme. So I think we can discount his article as being somewhat florid. But one of the things he really missed was this: the Department of Health and Aged Care has done an estimate of what it costs the Commonwealth on average for the health care of every uninsured person, and it is $1,041. The cost to the Commonwealth of an insured person under the current scheme is only $628, or, under the new scheme, $814. So that means that for every person you induce to go into private health insurance there is a minimum saving to the Commonwealth of about $227. I cannot see how you people can miss this. You all know that the Medicare levy, which started off at 1¼ per cent and is now 1½ per cent, covers only 20 per cent of the public health needs of Australia.

If you really wanted to have a user-pays system based on our taxation, you would have to raise the Medicare levy to 7½ per cent to break even. Doesn't it make more sense to encourage people to look after their own health care, especially when each person who does go onto private health insurance actually means a saving for the Commonwealth?

I think the member for Paterson knows in his heart of hearts—as do all of you in the opposition—that if we do not arrest this matter we will go down either the American way, where there will be one rule for the rich and one for the poor, or we will go down the UK way, where there will be a universal scheme with absolutely no choice; whereas we have had in Australia a very good parallel system. In fact, it was your great pride that in Queensland, when the Labor Party under the Hanlon government set up the free health scheme, we had a public hospital system and a private health system next to it. It worked very well, and subsequent coalition governments maintained it because it did work well. But when the Whitlam government came to power and forced Queensland into the national scheme, it went wrong from then on in Queensland and it went wrong all over Australia because your idea of solving problems is to throw money at them. Let me give you an example.

talk.start.para: —We are saving $720 million.

—No, you are not. You are not saving it at all. I have just made the point to you that if another eight per cent of people fall out of private health insurance, your $720 million will be gobbled up. It will be gobbled up not in that first year, but in subsequent years. I find it just mind-boggling that you cannot comprehend that. However, let me make another point. When we came to power in 1996, the cost of pharmaceuticals was increasing at the rate of 16 per cent a year. Their cost was doubling nearly every four years. All you did was let that run on. When we came to power we brought in a number of measures, such as increasing the co-payment, putting a premium on certain drugs, and devising a plan of more appropriate prescribing. Over the short period we have been in power, the increase in the cost of pharmaceuticals has dropped from 16 per cent to nine per cent. The point I am making is: whenever a problem like that occurred you just kept throwing more money at it. What we have done, without any great hardship to the Australian people, has steadied the scheme. You do not like to hear—
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, my apologies. But let me tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, of a very interesting answer which appeared in Hansard on 26 October 1993, where we have Senator Richardson responding to Senator Newman:

speech.para: In my view, we cannot continue to have private health insurance bleed in the way that it has in the past years because this does increase the strains on the public hospital system.
Then in 1994, in response to Senator Lees, he said:
We have to face the fact that in public hospitals around Australia there are people who are in pain and discomfort and who are waiting too long for treatment.
So I support my colleague the member for Boothby. The Labor Party has shown they have no credibility in this matter. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on this matter of public importance because I agree with ordinary Australians that our health system in this country is a matter of public importance. I am sorry that the government saw fit today to gag debate in this place and interrupted the honourable member for Rankin while he was giving a fine exposition of the problems in this area.

speech.para: The real threat to Australia's health system is the ideological opposition of those opposite to having a public health system at all. They are ideologically opposed to universal coverage, and they are setting out not just to defund the public system but to force all Australians to take out private health insurance.

Looking at the example of New South Wales alone—New South Wales is my home state—over the last three budgets New South Wales has suffered cuts of over $200 million from its health system. This is a contrast with the Carr Labor government's record. They have increased health funding in New South Wales by $1.3 billion. That is the difference. The major loss suffered by New South Wales is the totally unjustified cut of $103 million from the hospital funding grant. Despite repeated representations, the Howard government refuses to change this decision, which unfairly penalises the New South Wales public hospital system.

The abolition of the Commonwealth dental health program resulted in the accumulated loss of $95 million for the New South Wales public dental health system. The withdrawal of these funds has particularly impacted on rural New South Wales, causing hardship for the elderly and vulnerable groups in the community and resulting in the loss of 300 jobs in public dentistry. The Commonwealth cut another $6 million from the New South Wales hospital funding grant as a result of its unfair arbitration of cross-border issues with the ACT. Funding cuts of nearly $4 million have been imposed on a number of specific purpose programs, including on youth health, and so on. The list of cuts that the New South Wales system has suffered because of the Commonwealth government's actions in this area is long.

So what is the proposal the government comes to us with to improve the health system in this country? Is it to restore some of the funding it has cut from our public dental care system? Is it to provide the states with the $720 million per annum they have asked for as their ambit claim? This is an ambit claim, mind you. They have put in an ambit claim for $720 million. They say that would fix all of the problems in the public hospital system. Is this government prepared to talk to the states about that? No. What is the government going to do? It is going to spend $1.5 billion to increase private health insurance by only 2.7 per cent, on the Prime Minister's figures put before the House today. How shocking! The real matter of public concern here is that we have a government that is prepared to spend $1.5 billion of taxpayers' money to increase private health insurance coverage by only 2.7 per cent. Hardly money well spent, is it?

What is the reason people are leaving private health insurance? This government does not address any of the reasons that people leave private health insurance. People are leaving because of gap payments. They may have been paying private health insurance all their lives. Indeed, I have spoken to many of my constituents who have been privately insured over many years. Particularly in their later years they finally have cause to call on the services they have been paying for all these years, and what happens? It costs them money. In fact, it costs them more money being privately health insured than if they had not been insured. This is the only type of insurance that guarantees that you will have out-of-pocket expenses if you get sick or you have some misadventure. It costs you money if you are sick or you have some misadventure.

The other issue—and it is the unspoken issue in this debate—is specialists' fees in relation to gap payments. We all know that this government ran a very hardline ideological position on what they called a `closed shop' on the waterfront. They were prepared to take on the MUA with dogs and mace and balaclava-clad security guards—they were happy to do that with the MUA—but when the AMA raises its voice above a whisper what happens? The government turn to water. That is because the AMA and the colleges, the specialists, are pushing the government.

We certainly know what the insurance companies are doing by the fact that the members opposite have a list of every person in our electorates who is privately insured. To suggest that this is a public policy issue is ridiculous when we can see that the government are acting as the unofficial arm of the private health insurance industry. That is all they are doing. They are not making any sort of decision based on the public good, that's for sure.

The first reason that people are leaving private coverage is the gap, as I have described. The second reason is the up-front cost of private health insurance, which just continues to rise. Since 1989 the CPI has increased by slightly less than 30 per cent. By what margin do you think the cost of private health insurance has increased? The cost of private health insurance in that same time has increased by over 200 per cent. The comparison is 30 per cent with 200 per cent.

When the last lot of private health insurance incentives were introduced, what happened? Every private health insurer jacked up their premiums just as soon as they could. It is absurd, it is naive, to suggest that any further subsidy of private health insurance will not have exactly the same effect. You may as well just give them the money straight out. The Australian Financial Review, which is not normally a paper that I am taken to quoting, particularly its editorials, said:
The proposed rebate seems more calculated to elicit the gratitude of voters than a serious attempt to fix the problem. A big part of the money will go initially to people who are already insured—
we know that; it will be going to those people earning more than $70,000 a year, 72 per cent of whom are insured already—

rather than to the health sector, which makes the rebate a relatively inefficient, and inequitable, means of subsidising private health care provision. Eventually, like any subsidy, it will be shared with suppliers, as private hospitals, specialists and health funds put up their charges.
It does not take a genius to work that one out, does it? Ross Gittins writes in similar terms. He says:

This additional sum bought off the ire of the mere 30 per cent of the population who remain in private insurance, it bought off the doctors, private hospitals and health funds with a vested interest in the insurance system, and it bought him another term in office without a commitment to deal with root causes.
If you've heard of politicians throwing money at a problem, this is the classic case.

That is right: $1.5 billion of taxpayers' money will achieve an increase of 2.7 per cent in private health insurance coverage. What could we do with that $1.5 billion? Besides upgrading or building a few more Pacific highways, we could certainly improve the public health system. We could put that amount into schools, universities, child care. But how about dental care? An amount of $100 million has been cut from the Commonwealth Dental Service. People are coming in to see me to tell me that they are waiting two years to get their dentures. They are drinking and eating through straws.

What is most obscene about this is that at the same time as this government has cut $100 million from the Commonwealth Dental Scheme it is prepared to provide a non-means tested, non-capped rebate to people who have coverage for ancillary medical services—of course that includes dental services. How much is it going to end up paying out as a subsidy to people to take out private dental coverage? It will be $200 million. For $200 million, you could do an awful lot of work in the area of public dental care for the neediest people in our community. I have got the Sydney dental hospital in my electorate; they have told me that since the cuts to the Commonwealth dental scheme their waiting lists have increased at least fourfold. That is as a direct result of the $100 million cut from the Commonwealth Dental Service. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The opposition strongly supports the ratification of Australia's obligations as a signatory to the Ottawa Convention. I commend the government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs for this legislation. Over 120 countries have signed this convention and Australia will be one of approximately 40 countries to have ratified its signature at this time. Unfortunately, the US, Russia, China, Israel, Egypt, India, Pakistan, North Korea and South Korea have not signed the treaty. On a more regional basis, nor have Laos, Burma, Vietnam, Papua New Guinea or Singapore. Given our future lies in this region, Australia shares an interest in convincing these countries to sign the convention, and I think it is proper that we should use our influence to encourage them to do so.

speech.para: The convention signatories are prevented, under all circumstances, from using, producing, transferring, developing and stockpiling antipersonnel mines or helping any other country to do so. In addition, Australia must destroy its own existing antipersonnel mines within four years. Through this convention, Australia has also committed to provide assistance for mine and minefield clearance, education programs and support, and rehabilitation for mine victims, along with other signatories.

In my own life time, I have seen a complete turnabout in Australia's attitude to antipersonnel landmines. In the late 1960s as a member of the Pioneer Platoon, the 7th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment, I was trained in all aspects of mine warfare. That included laying mines and arming them, though it was never a task I had to do operationally. However, by the time I arrived in Vietnam in 1970, Australia was learning, at the cost of its soldiers, the folly of mine warfare. I quote Alan Stretton who, in his book Soldier in a Storm, said:

Another tactical error which cost many Australian lives was the laying of 23,000 mines in a minefield from Dat Do to the South China Sea without making satisfactory arrangements for its security. It was naive to the extreme to think that such a minefield could be protected by regional South Vietnamese forces and that they would be capable of stopping the Viet Cong from lifting the mines and using them as a source of supply in their operations against Australians. Some 8,000 mines were lifted from the field by the Viet Cong and caused death and injury to hundreds of young Australians. The situation became so bad that in 1969 more good Australian lives were sacrificed when the remaining mines left in the field were lifted by our own troops.

The fact is that the Viet Cong revolutionised mine warfare, and the modern era of indiscriminate mine use really began. Unfortunately, it continues to this day. Based on Red Cross figures, thousands of civilian men, women and children suffer the effects of landmines today.

Indeed, to quote the recently produced `Kids at war' Red Cross fact sheet under the heading `Children and landmines', it shows that more than 2,000 men, women and children a month are claimed by landmines. About 800 die, mainly children, and 1,200 are permanently mutilated. The International Red Cross provides 13,000 prostheses a year for amputees at an average cost of $160 each. A child of 10 will need 15 in his or her lifetime. There are an estimated 120 million uncleared landmines laid in 70 countries around the world.

That is the size of the task, but, to break that down into a human side, I want to quote from a story written by Sue Williams from the Sydney Morning Herald on 20 October this year. It is under the heading `Landmines girl pleads for help'. The article states:

She became the worldwide symbol of Princess Diana's campaign to rid the planet of landmines, but Angolan amputee Sandra Txijica faces being thrown out of school and banished to the tiny mud hut village where she was born.

Funds have nearly dried up for the little girl who won the hearts of millions when she was cradled in Diana's arms during an emotional visit to Angola by the Princess, shortly before she died. Angola, along with Cambodia, has the most landmines in the world.

Her image is still flashed across the world as a symbol of children's suffering as the scourge of landmines continues, and she appears in the video of Elton John's hit song Candle in the Wind , on stamps and in newspapers and magazines around the world.
But the sad truth is that Sandra may soon be forced to call off her quest.

Although her sweet face and shy brown eyes have become universally known, Sandra has never received a cent in royalties from those who have used her suffering to publicise the cause or make money for themselves.
"Many people have promised me money in return for helping them," said Sandra, 14, sitting in a hotel room in Sydney. "But no-one has sent any. It's very hard."

She has been relying on the charity of local aid workers to allow her to go to school and stay in the Angolan capital, Luanda, rather than return to work in the fields of her poverty-stricken home village in rebel-held territory.
That, however, is rapidly running out.
"I want to continue my work to help Princess Diana," she said.
"I feel very bad about the mines. They hurt so many people. I would like them to be finished everywhere."
Sandra, whose left leg was blown away when she stepped on a landmine at the age of four, is in Sydney on the start of a three-week visit to Australia, her first trip out of her trouble-torn country.
While she is tired and a little bewildered by all the sights she's seen since arriving on Friday night, she is happy to be here to continue Diana's work.

She'll be talking to Sydney schoolkids at an Australian Red Cross Kids At War seminar tomorrow about the landmines campaign, how the hidden evil has cost the lives and health of millions of children, and the joy of her day with Diana in January last year.
"She was so nice to me," said Sandra. "We sat and chatted about landmines and children. She had a simple personality and was very warm. She has helped so many children."

She's been visited by 70 journalists and photographers in Angola, who all pledged their help in return for writing stories and taking photos, but very little has been sent to be put towards her education, without which she will never have a future.

Local aid workers say it would be cruel to send her back to her remote rural village after her life has been changed so much by Diana's visit, but there may be no other option as meagre funds slowly dwindle.
"I just want to work to make sure no other children are killed or hurt by landmines," said Sandra.
"They have hurt me. I know what it can be like."

I had the pleasure of meeting Sandra just a few weeks ago when I went to Sydney for the Red Cross. She is a delightful young woman and she puts an extremely brave but compassionate human face on the universal tragedy of landmines. That is exactly why I have referred to it today.

Much mention is made of Princess Diana's work of focussing attention on the tragedy of landmine victims, and I certainly appreciate the focus she gave the issue. There are many people in Australia who too should take great credit for the way in which the fight for the ban on landmines has been waged. I refer to people like Sister Patricia Pak Poy, the Australian coordinator of the international campaign to ban landmines, and to the many other people in non-government organisations, including Austcare and the Red Cross, who have worked hand in hand to bring this issue to where it is today.

It is these non-government organisations which have been the driving force behind the Ottawa Convention, and I commend them for their commitment and resolute dedication and determination to the position which this parliament is about to ratify. It is through the efforts of these organisations that a path was established and a lead set that governments simply had no option but to follow.

I am involved in a number of anti-landmine organisations—among them is the WA Community Liaison and Advisory Committee of the de-mining research project at the University of Western Australia. The research team, under Professor James Trevelyan, is the only team in the world to investigate de-mining problems in depth and to talk to de-miners in the field to learn about their problems. A reflection of their expertise is that they are mainly funded by the United States Defence Department. I sought the views of Professor Trevelyan and he provided the following, and I quote from the briefing notes we discussed:

In supporting this legislation, we would like to take this opportunity to raise the issue of mine clearance: a worthy objective to which the government has committed $100 million over the ten years to 2005. This issue is particularly relevant to section 6/4 of the Convention.

We are concerned that this money could be spent more effectively. While over 35 million has already been committed, there seems to be no clear strategy to maximise the effectiveness of this major expenditure by Australian taxpayers. Grants are announced seemingly on an ad-hoc basis without concern for overall efficiency and long term objectives.

At The University of Western Australia we have researched the practical problems of mine clearance for three years and have achieved wide international recognition for our work. We have solved several practical problems faced by deminers. By closely analysing accident records we have devised light-weight, cheap and comfortable protective clothing and tools for deminers to minimise the risk of injuries.

Unlike many research programmes which focus on technology alone, ours is broadly based because we have learned that social, cultural and political factors dictate solutions as much as technical factors.

We have discovered that currently there are no ways to accurately assess the effectiveness of a mine clearance programme taking the huge diversity of tasks into account. Simply calculating dollars per mine destroyed is meaningless when one realises that many mine fields may contain no active mines at all. Yet as long as the land is thought to be mined, it cannot safely be re-settled or used to grow food.

We have also learned that nearly every demining programme is entirely dependent on foreign aid funding and most rely heavily on ex-patriate experts who cost $200,000 to $300,000 a year and often stay only a few months. Local deminers know more about the mine problem than foreign experts, but have mostly been denied the formal education we all take for granted and have limited fluency in English. Their views are suppressed, leading to frustration and resentment. The Afghanistan Mine Action Programme was set up predominantly by Australians and is now recognised as being the best in the world. Over 4,000 Afghans work in the programme yet only four or five ex-patriate experts are involved in a monitoring and advisory role and they are mostly on long-term appointments. All the major demining organisations are staffed entirely by Afghans.

Even the Afghanistan programme is entirely reliant on aid funding. Yet the problems of mines and unexploded ordnance last long after aid programmes cease. Germany is still spending more than $1 billion a year clearing explosive devices left over from World Wars 1 and 2. The only long term solution is to build local capacity to handle the problems which means rebuilding the economies and training people.
We know of several people whose expertise is available such as Mr. Bill van Ree who managed the Afghanistan Mine Action Programme until the end of 1997.

The long term benefits of our demining commitment will be greatly enhanced by ensuring that it is appropriately supported by a coordinated programme of research, education and training, particularly for senior demining staff. Such a programme would significantly boost local capabilities in all the countries we currently support. This needs to be based in mine-affected regions with local staff. Yet Australia has the resources to ensure senior deminers in different countries learn as much or more from each other as much as from Australian expertise.

The University of Western Australia has shown how an in-country research team can work successfully with an Australian university, with much better outcomes for both from a given level of funding. The in-country research team will lead to a locally self-sustainable organisation manufacturing equipment tailored to the needs of Afghan deminers.

Finally there are many serving defence force personnel who would gladly spend a year or more assisting demining programmes in our region: many have already taken part in demining programmes before. Yet the Defence Department insists on full cost recovery for their services without taking into account the enormous benefits received. These people enhance Australia's standing in the region, and make personal contacts in regions where the ADF may be called on to operate in future. They learn about the tactics of armed groups, and in particular practice decontamination in real situations, rather than dry and unrealistic training exercises in Australia.

Through Professor Trevelyan, I also sought the views of Mr Bill van Ree who, as was mentioned, oversaw the very successful Afghanistan mine action program. Mr van Ree also works in the field for Austcare, and he had this to say:

The development of a successful mine action program should be based on the development of four aspects. (1) Education, community understanding of the mines problem and the difficulties associated with clearance and the communities role in the clearance process. (2) Training, this not only includes the development of the technical skills to located and destroy mines and UXOs but, more importantly, the development of the management science of effective mine action. (3) Data collection and the development of information management systems that provide the information needed to identify and make use of opportunities to improve safety, productivity and effectiveness of the program. (4) Victim assistance, including medical support for those injured by mines and assistance in the development of livelihoods for those denied access to safe productive land.

One of the areas that we could improve is the application of Army resources to mine action. While it would be ideal to have a percentage of the defence budget allocated to mine action, I understand that this may be extremely difficult to achieve. However, one issue that should be addressed is the employment of defence force personnel in mine action projects. Australian Army staff have a well deserved reputation for excellence in mine clearance. They seem to have adapted to the challenge of working in this field gaining the support and respect of many working in the humanitarian aid sector, extremely difficult to achieve when you are a soldier.

Unfortunately, the department of defence charges AusAID "full cost recovery" (as I understand it) for each member of the defence force involved in these projects. I believe that the Army should not charge for these people. Most of the members involved see these projects as an extremely valuable training and staff development opportunity. Members have the opportunity to develop contaminated area clearance skills and a broader understanding on the employment and eradication of landmines. They are exposed to opportunities to develop skills in battlefield analysis and exposure to countries in our region of strategic importance. The Army could get better value from this opportunity by: (1) getting Army volunteers to spend longer periods on demining tours (say 12 months Vs the normal 3-6 months) and (2) tasking the soldiers with self and army development of lessons learned (eg. Papers on battlefield analysis and the employment of mines, and the development of technologies in the location and destruction of mines, the development of mine detection etc). This may not seem to be an important issue but, one of the things that I have noticed over the past few years is that many of the people involved in the development of mine action management at the operational level do not have the battlefield analysis skills needed to reduce the time wasted on checking areas that do not contain mines. We have the opportunity to make a very valuable contribution to mine action and the development of our own Army.

Of real concern to me is the issue of how and where we are to spend the $100 Mil announced this time last year, (now estimated to be about $65 mil remaining). The problem here is that AusAID appears to have a glass ceiling for the allocation of funds.

AusAID tends to avoid exposure to high startup costs by channelling funds through the UN Trust Funds established to support mine action. This is a good approach, provided you are satisfied with the direction and performance of the supported organisation. I would prefer to seek critical analysis of individual projects and for AusAID to consider the option of channelling funds through an Australian Mine Action NGO that can develop the management and technical technologies that seem to be difficult to develop within the larger Bureaucracies. This organisation should be seen as a catalyst for change in the management of mine action projects in beneficiary communities.

I support the views of people like Professor Trevelyan and Bill van Ree. They are on the sharp end of landmine clearance; they command respect. I would like to encourage the minister and the government to listen to and act on the very good suggestions that these people have.

In relation to the $100 million, I would also be appreciative if the minister in his response could give the House details of the following: (1) the proposed expenditure of the remaining money; (2) a break down of the money already spent; (3) in which department or departments will budgeted moneys be held; (4) what amounts will be budgeted on a yearly basis up to the year 2005; (5) who will decide how much, and where, the money will be spent, and against what criteria; and (6) if any, what part of the $100 million will be by way of resource rather than financial support?

I strongly urge the minister to ensure that this money or in kind support, if that is the case, is channelled through Australian agencies. There is absolutely no doubt that they are among world leaders in the fight against the horror of landmines. For instance, Austcare has now decided that, rather than funding other people, they themselves are going operational and employing their own teams. I say to the minister that it is agencies like the Red Cross and Austcare which will give Australia best value for money. I would urge him and the government to establish a representative body of non-government organisation representatives to give advice on how best to spend the moneys available and to ensure that the greatest possible impact is made in the shortest possible time.

I want to draw the minister's attention to part 2, clause 7(3) of the bill. I ask the minister if he could give this House an assurance that this clause will not be used as a loophole to assist countries which are not signatories to this convention. I would also like an assurance that Australian defence personnel will know exactly what their guidelines are in relation to their responsibilities under this legislation. I want to be assured that defence personnel acting in good faith will have sufficient safeguards when involved in or supporting international operations.

I join with Mr Bill van Ree and the Western Australian de-mining project in calling on the government to recognise the benefits of our defence forces taking an active role in de-mining programs in our region and making their personnel available at minimal cost. This will significantly enhance our de-mining commitment without increased cost to taxpayers. I also join with them in calling on the Australian government to draw on, as I have already said, the knowledge and expertise available in Australia to redirect Australian resources to maximise the long-term effectiveness of our de-mining commitment.

I brought a couple of landmines with me today—and I assure you that they have been neutered—because in my discussions with people, even with some members of parliament, many do not have an idea of what landmines look like. I am sorry that Hansard cannot capture this image, but what I am holding up is a landmine which has been used since about 1970. The smaller landmine that I have is probably a little over two inches wide and two inches deep. It is a mine which is designed not necessarily to kill but to blow someone's leg off or injure them in such a way that their colleagues would be forced to look after and care for them. The great trag edy is that when mines are left in the ground they do not discriminate. They do not know the difference between a soldier and a civilian. They do not know the difference between a man, a woman or a child. When they explode, they either kill or maim.

I also have with me a danger sign which is used in places like Cambodia. It is made of a fairly stiff type of plastic. Unfortunately, in the countries and the regions in which they are used, the people are extremely poor, and they have a habit of taking these warning signs and using them for tiles. As a consequence, AusAID and others have been forced to cut a boomerang portion out of each side so that they are no longer useful for such a purpose. These two instances—one, the very small size of the mines and, two, the difficulty in warning people of the whereabouts of mines—are reasons why we have the very high casualty rates that I spoke about a bit earlier—casualty rates that have been identified by the Red Cross.

It is a matter of extreme importance that Australia has signed this convention. It is important that we ratify the convention, which is what this legislation will do. It is important that we do not stop there; that we use our money and our resources in the best possible way. In this way we can ensure that the number of Sandras injured—the young girl to whom I referred earlier—is kept to a bare minimum. The unfortunate thing is that there are hundreds of Sandras out there in the community in very different parts of the world. Some have already suffered injuries, and there are many hundreds who are yet to experience them, simply because there are so many landmines in various parts of the world.

The great tragedy is that these kids, simply at play doing what every child should have a right to do in any part of the world, set off these landmines and suffer the great injuries that we have seen happen to this young girl Sandra. I am very pleased that Australia is standing up to take its responsibility as a leader in the world on these issues. In closing, I thank my colleagues for giving me the opportunity to handle this bill for the opposition.

talk.start.para: —I will start my speech on the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 by congratulating the member for Cowan on an outstanding contribution. He obviously has a deep and abiding interest in this subject and a considerable degree of expertise, and I, and I am sure all other members of this House, would like to acknowledge his contribution and thank him for it.

speech.para: I grew up in England—and I date myself by saying this—during the Second World War. As I grew up and went through school, I remember and became quite used to seeing grown men—men who were younger than I am today, some from the First World War and some from the Second World War—walking down the street on crutches, perhaps with a limb missing. It was not a common sight, but it was certainly not uncommon. It was something that, I suppose, one understood happened.

Of course, many of those injuries were caused by landmines. I saw the impact they had on many of those men's lives. Whilst today we have in place good social security systems to help people who were affected in that situation, in those days that was not necessarily the case. Whilst some people have the personal characteristics to get over such terrible injuries, not everybody does and the impact can be terrible. One of my own grandfathers lost a leg in that way in the First World War. He died before I really grew up very much, but I remember his being so immobilised in that way.

Later in my life I spent some two dozen years in the British Air Force. I served in Singapore during the Malayan emergency and subsequently elsewhere. Again, although fortunately I did not have to experience landmines directly, I certainly saw their effects on others with whom I served. After my military service I left the Air Force. I migrated to Australia 20 years ago and went into business and, probably like so many Australians, it slipped from my mind. It was not there consciously. I did not think about it too much. I was too busy trying to make a quid and put a roof over the family, and I think most Australians would be in that situation.

Thankfully, most of our population probably have never had to face, have needed to know about or have actually experienced, landmines and their consequences, and that is a blessing. But it is an issue that we all need to be aware of. In this country it is not a reality perhaps every day, but the reality in so many parts of the world is the impact of landmines—and the ongoing impact of landmines across large parts of the world is very severe indeed.

Since I have been in this parliament, I have been fortunate enough to make a number of visits overseas with parliamentary delegations. On two delegation visits to Pakistan, I had the opportunity to meet some of the de-mining teams that the member for Cowan referred to who were operating in Pakistan and training de-miners to go back into Afghanistan. I toured some of the refugee camps and I saw some of the de-mining activity there. Of course, the impact on many of those people was really quite horrendous.

On my first visit to Pakistan about six years ago, we actually had Australian Defence de-mining personnel working on the ground training local people to gain some expertise in de-mining. When I went back a year or two ago, we had withdrawn our military personnel from there. We had decided that the priority was in Cambodia or somewhere else—and that may well have been the right decision, but it meant that we were therefore dependent totally on non-government organisations.

One of the things that struck me was that most of the expert de-mining personnel who were there in a non-government capacity were former serving officers and NCOs of the Australian forces, some of whom had decided when we withdrew the military from that area to resign their commissions and go back there on a voluntary basis. The commitment was that great. I can well identify with the comments of the member for Cowan about the need or the desire of many of our existing servicemen to take the opportunity to go to those places and undertake that training and very vital work.

The government has put a fair amount of money and effort over the years, as have all governments from this country, to try to alleviate some of these problems. Training volunteers is a long and tortuous business, and the depths of expertise certainly is not always there. Only last year I had the opportunity to visit Laos on a delegation led by the parliamentary secretary who is at the table, the member for Moncrieff. Again we visited a de-mining location. I think the member for Cowan has upstaged me because I brought my little demonstration as well.

While we were there, we learnt that, for example, the Americans did blanket bombing during the Vietnam War and other conflicts associated with that area. I do not know the technical name, but basically they would drop several dozen, if not hundreds, of these bombs in a single bombing load, the bombs would open up as they came down and some 600 of these little round landmines would come out of each bomb.

For the benefit of Hansard's description, I am holding up a wooden copy of the actual thing, but it is really just a little ball no bigger than a tennis ball. It has no real distinctive marks on the outer shell. These were scattered far and wide throughout Indo-China. If you go to Laos, which is a very poor small country, these things and other landmines in a whole variety of shapes and forms are scattered all over the place.

But, when you are a little kid of four or five running around the fields and you pick up a little ball like the one I am holding—and there are literally millions of these things all over the country—you do not understand what it is. De-mining signs may not be there. Young kids do not pay attention to warnings. We talk to our kids or our grandchildren and tell them what they should and should not do and half the time they do not listen. So a kiddie will come along and pick this up and start playing with it, or throw it to his mate, and boom—he is blinded, he is dead, he has lost an arm, he has lost a leg or whatever.

There are literally millions of these all over the place in many countries of Asia—Cambodia, Laos and so on. It means that, if you go out into the rice paddy, you might not come back because you might walk on a mine. If you want to clear some ground to build a house and get some economic development going, you may find that one of these things is under the ground that you are trying to clear and blows up in your face. So the social impact, the economic impact and the human impact of landmines is absolutely horrendous. It is something which most of us really never come to grips with.

It is an everyday risk for people who live in those areas, so I am very pleased that the government has chosen to introduce this bill. The bill is to give effect to our obligations as party to the Convention on the Prohibition of the Use, Stockpiling, Production and Transfer of Anti-Personnel Mines and on their Destruction—in other words, the Ottawa Convention.

I am not going to go through this in great detail because time is limited today, but the object of the legislation is to make sure that we do not use land mines in a war situation, that we do retain a small capability within the armed forces for training of people in a de-mining capacity, and that we allow inspections of our country—as others will have to allow inspections of their territory—to make sure that we implement it. There are a number of other technical things there. I am pleased of course that the opposition is supporting this legislation but, frankly, I think that is almost a foregone conclusion because all of us in this place would support this type of legislation, whoever brought it forward.

Over 130 countries have already signed the convention, which I think is clearly in tune with the spirit of the times and goes a considerable way towards building a global norm against landmines. I agree with the previous speaker that we, as a country, not only need to put money and expertise into this area, which is so vital, but also need to go out and convince a lot of our neighbours in this region—where, in fact, we have good standing these days because our help in other ways in recent years—who have not signed the convention to do so.

The thought of landmines causing death or injury of nearly 2,000 people per month, every month, in this year of 1998—and it will go on into next year and into the new millennium—is totally unacceptable. Therefore, it is important that this country tries to do something about it and that we support the convention.

In the last parliament I had the privilege of being chair of the Amnesty group and of being heavily involved with defence, foreign affairs and trade committees in one form or another, and so I have had the opportunity be close to some of these issues. I am delighted that I have been able to be somewhat associated with the ministers bringing in this legislation. I congratulate the government and the minister, and I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure for me to participate in this debate this evening on the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 , particularly following the contributions made by the member for Cowan on behalf of the opposition and also by the member for Aston. In both contributions by my colleagues, they have clearly demonstrated the commitment that the whole of this parliament has to ensuring the swift passage of this legislation. I would like to lend my support to the congratulations that have gone to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and to the Minister for Defence in the previous government, who lent his assistance—I am sure the present minister would like to be associated with that—and also to my colleagues on this side of the parliament who have been pushing for this particular legislation for some time.

speech.para: I am sure honourable members with long memories in this place would know that, on our side particularly, it was an issue which had been on the agenda for probably far too long. It was an issue that we could have probably come to in our term in government a little sooner, but nevertheless that should not take away from the fact that we are here this evening in very much a bipartisan spirit in supporting this legislation. At the end of the day this goes to the very heart of issues around the world in terms of both warfare and post-war reconstruction. As both colleagues have ably demonstrated—and regrettably I have not got for Hansard or, indeed, for the parliament something to demonstrate here this evening—the simple fact is that military material, which landmines are, last in places where they have been laid well beyond any of the wars for which their original purpose was foreseen.

Any statistics that you look at would tell you something about the breadth of this particular problem: there are something like 60 million to 70 million landmines scattered across 70 countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, the Middle East and the Americas; 50 years is the average life of a landmine; 2,000 people, on average, are killed or injured by landmines each month; $3 to $30 is the cost of producing a landmine; $300 to $1,000 dollars is the cost of neutralising a landmine; $4,000 is needed per amputee for surgical care and prosthesis; one out of every 236 people in Cambodia is an amputee due to landmine injuries; and 20,000 people in Angola are amputees due to landmines. These statistics come from the United Nations and also from the International Committee of the Red Cross. They demonstrate that long after a conflict has passed in many parts of the world the devastation and the destruction continues, and it is the innocents who are the ones most greatly affected.

I think recently there was even evidence that suggested, as a result of some of the heavy rains in South-East Asia—some of the storms, some of the very intense seasonal tropical downpours that occurred there—there has been massive land movement, landslip, and all sorts of these destructive landmines have been uncovered. As the member for Aston has described, literally millions of them have just now been uncovered.

The most regrettable feature of this is that productive parts of many of these developing countries are still unable to be used productively because of the laying of landmines at different times. In many of these countries, if they are to prosper—the honourable member talked of Laos, but I am sure that there are many other examples as well—they need every square inch of their arable land for development purposes. They need every square inch of their land in outer urban fringes to ensure that appropriate economic development takes place. But if they are subject to enormous costs associated with landmine clearing then, clearly, that is going to impact on the ability of those countries to rehabilitate themselves. Countries like Australia have a genuine and very real commitment to do something about that, as we should.

I am very pleased to be Labor's spokesperson on defence issues in this parliament because we do have a very proud record in our defence forces—and I say this very much in a bipartisan way—in respect of mine clearing operations. I think even the most charitable members on both sides of this place would have to say that our former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Gareth Evans, did an outstanding job in respect of Cambodia and that the ongoing relationship that was established between Australia's defence forces in clearing mines was very much part of the process of rehabilitation of that former war-torn country.

I think it is also important that we understand that the bipartisan nature of this legislation also has its genesis in the fact that both sides of parliament—and dare I say all political parties—have at some stage in recent times adopted a common policy in respect of this. In the case of the Australian Labor Party, at our Hobart national conference in January of this year we adopted a specific resolution as part of our platform, which states:
