In response to the global humanitarian crisis arising from the scourge of anti-personnel landmines, Labor is committed to working in all available forums to secure a global and legally binding ban on the use, production, transfer and stockpiling of anti-personnel landmines, and to supporting those efforts through ratification of the Ottawa landmines ban treaty and destruction of Australia's landmine stockpile, with the exception of the minimum stocks required for mine clearance and awareness training by the Australian Defence Force.

I think that is the sort of resolution that anybody in this place would live with—whether it was at a Labor Party national conference, whether it was at a conference of the Liberal Party or whatever—because of the destructive and insidious nature of these weapons of destruction, which are not totally dissimilar to large guns or the use of FA18 fighters, F111s, naval bombardments, subma rines or whatever it might be. These aspects of war, as all contributors in the debate this afternoon have highlighted, are there for a long time after the event. For this reason, as I said a little earlier, it is welcome that this legislation is before us today.

I noted in some of the information provided by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on Australian de-mining aid projects, which the member for Cowan also reflected upon, that a number of countries serve as very good examples as to how this takes place and why it should occur. I will take Cambodia and Laos as examples. Australian government aid has assisted in the detection and destruction of mines and unexploded ordnance in Cambodia and Laos. Through mine and UXO clearance activities and mine awareness education, Australia is helping the people of Cambodia and Laos pursue the task of reconstruction and development in a safer environment.

According to the statistics in this document, Australian soldiers and civilian personnel have been working to provide training and organisational support to help Cambodians clear landmines, using the latest Australian technology, and something like 520,000 mines have been cleared. Yet, as I think we all appreciate, that is only a fraction of the ordnance that was distributed during the term of the Cambodian conflict.

Afghanistan is one of the most heavily mined countries in the world. Each day 10 Afghans are killed or maimed by landmines. With 90 per cent of Afghanistan's mined areas in agricultural fields, irrigation canals and grazing areas, economic recovery will be severely hampered until the mines are removed. The Australian government has funded landmine awareness and de-mining projects since 1991 in that country.

Landmine detector and sniffer dog teams have cleared more than 152 square kilometres of mine infested land in Afghanistan's eastern provinces since 1989. Even that statistic tells you the size of the task. Since 1989 we have been involved in a project in Afghanistan and yet we have been able to assist in de-mining only 152 square kilometres of that country, which is the most heavily mined country in the world. That illustrates the commitment that we in this country do have and why it should continue. The document goes on to talk about Angola, Mozambique and other countries. It is quite amazing when you look at those statistics.

The section of the legislation which says—and which we have all agreed is an important part of the legislation—that the Australian Defence Force can maintain a small supply of these mines for training purposes is very significant. It is significant because we have a proud history in our Australian Defence Force of mine clearance operations. We have highly trained, highly skilled personnel who are carrying out these operations around the world at no small risk to themselves. That part of this legislation provides an enduring opportunity for Australia's defence forces to maintain those significant training opportunities for our service people and also to assist in the economic recovery of many of these countries where we have been sent in the past.

That section of the legislation also makes a significant contribution to our regional security and stability because there is no doubt conventional arguments about what is warfare change all the time. Warfare today can be economic warfare. Warfare today can be sending somebody like that stockbroker in Singapore to see what he can do on behalf of a bank to bring the country to its knees. That is warfare in a sense. It is a practised art—perhaps a black art—but it is one which is emerging more and more.

The simple fact is that there will always be a need—at the pointy edge of defence—for trained personnel equipped and ready to fulfil Australia's international obligation as part of our regional security and regional stability commitment. I would like to think that the continuing presence of Australia's Defence Force plus the ongoing research and development of how these landmine eradication projects might continue, as carried out by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, might receive the recognition of this parliament that they so rightly deserve. There is a technical component; there is a military component. Both sides of defence have been doing a marvellous job, and they should be commended for it. The government, too, should be commended for this legislation. It is timely, it is welcomed by the opposition and we wish it speedy passage through this place.

talk.start.para: —As the Howard government's Special Representative on Demining, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I speak to the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 . The bill is the culmination of much hard work by many with the single aim of putting an end to a blight that has killed and maimed countless innocent victims around the globe. I have seen the nature of the landmine problem at first hand and have met many of the people whose lives have been changed forever by this terrible scourge. That is why the passage of this legislation will give me particular satisfaction.

speech.para: Last May I had the privilege of leading the Australian delegation at the Global Humanitarian Demining Conference in Washington. The conference provided a unique opportunity to discuss the many and complex issues associated with landmines and I congratulate the United States government for initiating and hosting it.

Australia's close involvement in this issue is entirely one of principle. It should be a matter of pride for us that not only has the Australian Defence Force never been associated with the indiscriminate or irresponsible use of landmines, but rather ADF personnel have put their own lives at risk as members of de-mining teams that Australia has provided to countries in need of their expertise.

Honourable members are probably familiar with the grim statistics on landmines, some of which have already been mentioned. There are 70 million landmines in more than 70 countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, the Middle East and the Americas. Approximately 2,000 people are killed or injured by landmines each month, half of whom are women and children. An average of 10 Afghanis are killed or maimed by landmines each day. Landmine injuries have made amputees of more than 44,000 Cambodians—one in every 236—20,000 Angolans and 8,000 Mozambicans.

There is no doubt that the relatively low monetary cost of landmines—as little as $3 per mine—has contributed to their indiscriminate use in armed conflicts. They can be spread quickly and easily. Some, for example butterfly and dragontooth mines, can be dropped from helicopters at the rate of more than 1,000 per minute. When the time comes to remove these mines, it is a different story. It can cost $1,000 to neutralise just one mine in a procedure that is not only expensive and very dangerous but also tedious and lengthy. It can take an entire day to clear a mere 20 square metres of mine contaminated land. Further, many mines are very long-lived and can continue to strike for up to 50 years after the end of the conflict for which they were laid.

One of the saddest stories I have heard relates to Hurricane Mitch, the storm that recently devastated so many countries in Central America and the Caribbean. Landmines laid along the Nicaraguan border more than a decade ago were displaced by the hurricane's floods, killing and maiming rescue workers and those involved in the clean-up—yet another tragic example of how landmines strike indiscriminately.

The recent United Nations report entitled The impact of armed conflict on children outlines the nature of the problem. Signs posted to warn of landmines are useless if children are too young to read or are illiterate for other reasons. Children's small and fragile bodies mean that they are far more likely to die from their mine injuries than adults or, if they survive, they are likely to be more seriously injured or permanently disabled. Because children are still growing, their wounds may require repeated amputation and a new artificial limb as often as every six months. Children, with no direct economic or political influence, often lose out on rehabilitative therapy in an environment of scarce medical resources.

The human cost of landmines is not limited to deaths and injuries caused directly by mine explosions. The very fear of their presence can render unusable large areas of otherwise productive land, which can have dire consequences for food production and may also prevent refugees returning to their homes. This loss of agricultural land can lead to malnutrition and even starvation. De-mining agricultural land can give people the chance to grow their own crops rather than rely on international aid. Australian de-miners in Mozambique had some first-hand experience of just how valuable that land could be. At one stage, they were clearing narrow strips of land only about a metre wide each day. Each time they came back to start work the next morning, they would find the previous day's cleared strip already planted with crops.

I have already mentioned the work done by Australia to assist in worldwide de-mining efforts. As part of our discussion of the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 which outlaws the possession, use of and trade in landmines, I think it is worth putting on the record the significant contribution Australia makes in relation to de-mining and related activities. We can all be proud of it. Australia has always responded speedily and generously to calls for assistance and has been a substantial contributor to de-mining programs in the most heavily mined countries in the world.

In December last year, the Minister for Foreign Affairs announced that, for the 10 years from 1995 to 2005, Australia would provide more than $100 million for de-mining and related activities. Already $35 million has been committed, making Australia a major donor in assisting with de-mining, mine awareness and victim assistance. This $35 million comes from the overseas aid budget and excludes any expenditure by the Department of Defence on humanitarian de-mining.

Australian assistance has concentrated on four areas: institutional support for mine clearance organisations; physical clearance of landmines and training of indigenous de-mining teams; mine awareness activities focussing on local communities and school children; and treatment and rehabilitation for landmine victims to help restore mobility and employment opportunities. Our assistance is channelled in various ways, including through the United Nations, non-government organisations and Australian Defence Force personnel. The majority has been directed to countries in Australia's immediate region, particularly Cambodia and Laos, but significant support has also been provided to Angola, Mozambique, Afghanistan and now Sri Lanka.

Some honourable members may have visited one of our programs during parliamentary delegation visits to these countries and have had the opportunity, like me, to see the great work that is being done. I take this opportunity to acknowledge the magnificent efforts of our de-mining aid workers, often in circumstances of considerable personal danger.

Following the Conference on Global Humanitarian Demining in Washington, Australia has been working with other countries on coordination of de-mining initiatives through the United Nations Mine Action Service, or UNMAS, the creation of which has significantly enhanced the coordination of international efforts. In line with the recommendations of the Washington conference, we are looking at support for multidisciplinary assessments of each mine affected country, development of mine surveys, determination of common standards for the development and application of technology to humanitarian de-mining and for the development of information management systems that can both inform donors and promote better coordination.

I say to the member for Cowan, who made some comments that perhaps Australia's forward planning was not as structured as it might be—I think that is a fair precis of what he might have said—that this conference was extremely important in that context.

talk.start.para: —I was quoting Mr Bill van Ree whom you may know.

—Yes, in relation to the comments—you did quote them and they are in the record—I need to say that that Washington conference was highly relevant to this very point. Its purpose was that the 30-odd countries that are donors to worldwide de-mining activities could have a better future structure in terms of identifying what the problem really is and its scope, and identifying priority areas—and there are some landmined areas that are not of high priority for clearance—and making sure that in-country there is good coordination of everybody involved. That is the significance of the role of UNMAS.
—It is also the sort of work that the University of Western Australia is doing.
—I am aware that they are doing good work. A number of universities in Australia have a keen interest in the subject for one reason or another. It is very welcome.

speech.para: I make that intervention in relation to the contribution by the member for Cowan to say that in the past it has actually been difficult for donor countries to find a structure within which they could work. Without doubt, there is enormous goodwill worldwide—and not least in Australia—to do what can be done for poor countries, in particular, that are affected. But there has not been the best-quality information available. We have responded in relation to identified need and tried to make sure that our aid money is put to the best possible use.

I want to take this opportunity to particularly commend to honourable members on both sides of the House an initiative in which they could involve themselves within their own electorates—namely, Destroy a Minefield, a mine clearance and awareness program recently announced by the government. This program will allow individuals, schools, community groups, business and associations to participate directly in solving the landmines problem by adopting active minefields which have been selected by the United Nations as having a high priority for clearance so as to return the land to productive use by the local population. This type of project is already under way in the United States and I believe will spread to a number of countries throughout the world.

Destroy a Minefield will receive funds from the Princess Diana Trust Fund set up to collect the sales tax revenue from the Elton John Candle in the wind tribute CD in memory of the late Princess of Wales. The government will allocate $200,000 from the trust fund and will also contribute an additional $200,000 from our overseas aid budget. Individual or group sponsors will be encour aged to raise funds to clear their adopted minefield. For every $2 raised by sponsors, the Princess Diana Trust Fund and the government will contribute $1. The Australian community can thus activate $1.2 million towards high priority minefield clearance. Destroy a Minefield will not only benefit poor people who live in daily fear of landmines but also educate and involve altruistic Australians in the landmine issue in a compassionate and productive way.

The bill we are considering today will be a major step forward in the effort to achieve a total ban on landmines. Australia, along with the 120 other countries that have also signed the Ottawa Convention, is entering into a legally binding commitment forswearing the use, stockpiling, production and transfer of antipersonnel landmines. This is an achievement of major international and domestic significance. Passage of this legislation will also mean that Australia will be in a position to ratify the convention by the time it enters into force on 1 March 1999.

But this is not the end of the story. The list of convention signatory nations does not include key countries in the global landmines equation; that is, some of the major producers and users of landmines. That is why this government has ensured that Australia continues to play a leading role in pushing for complementary negotiations in the UN-affiliated Conference on Disarmament to achieve a ban on transfers; namely, all forms of trading and transportation of antipersonnel mines. Such a ban, if adopted by those major traditional producers and traders in landmines who have not signed the Ottawa Convention, would represent a very important step forward in the global battle against landmines.

Some time ago, Australia ratified the Revised Landmines Protocol—Protocol II—to the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons. The protocol involves measures such as ensuring the detectability and self-destructibility of mines and the outlawing of the use of mines against the civilian population. We continue to encourage all states which have not yet done so—and particularly those which have not or do not sign the Ottawa Convention—to become parties to the convention and the Revised Protocol. We are active in promoting adherence to the Revised Protocol in our region.

What we are seeing is the development of a number of overlapping conventions and protocols with the ultimate objective of a truly global, comprehensive ban on antipersonnel landmines. The Australian government remains committed to that objective.

The Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 will give effect to Australia's obligations under the Ottawa Convention. It will make it an offence to engage in activities prohibited under the convention, with penalties of up to 10 years imprisonment. The placement, possession, development, production, acquisition, stockpiling and transfer of antipersonnel mines by ADF members or Australian citizens will be outlawed. At the same time, an appropriate exemption will allow the retention of a minimal number of mines for anti-mine and mine clearance training. This is an outcome of which all Australians can be proud. It is a result in which honourable members can also take pride, for I know that members on both sides of the House have struggled long and hard for it.

While this marks one milestone towards the goal of a world free from landmines, the Howard government is determined to ensure that there will be many more causes for celebration. We will keep pressing these matters in international forums. We will continue our assistance with de-mining and related activities both bilaterally and multilaterally. In that task, each square metre of land returned to production will mark a victory. Each person spared from death or terrible injury will be ample reward. It is therefore in that happy anticipation that I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —In joining in this debate, I think it is worth commenting on the quality of contributions made by members on both sides of the House. We are all horribly aware of what indiscriminate killers and maimers of human beings antipersonnel landmines are. We are aware that the great majority of their victims are civilians, and a very large percentage of their victims are children. One has to wonder what sort of human being it is that sits down to deliberately design a product to attract a child of the type that the member for Aston showed the chamber today, or what sort of company it is that produces that sort of horrific device.

speech.para: We are all also aware of the massive costs that are imposed upon communities. Tragically, those communities are usually those least able to sustain not only the costs of clearing up mines but also the huge loss associated with the loss of productive land from those minefields. Countries such as Ethiopia, Somalia and Sudan seem to face perennial famine conditions with mines preventing access to limited water resources and limited available arable land.

The statistics, as other speakers have indicated, are horrific. The parliamentary secretary referred to, I think, 70 million mines in 70 countries. Other people estimate well in excess of 100 million mines.
Mrs Sullivan interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Is it? Nonetheless, it is an horrific number whether it is 70 million or over 100 million in typically poor countries such as Cambodia, Afghanistan, Angola and Bosnia. In Angola, there is estimated to be more landmines than people. In Cambodia, one in every 236 people is an amputee. In the order of 20 per cent of the casualties are children and it is estimated that 26,000 people—that is, one every 20 minutes—are injured by these horrific weapons.

speech.para: The problems of clearing up have been amply indicated elsewhere in the debate. The cost of detecting and removing these devices is up to $US1,000. These devices also impose a range of other problems on the global community—dangers to peacekeepers, for example. I have seen figures recently that show that 42 peacekeepers in the former Yugoslavia have been killed and some 315 injured as a result of landmines.

The abhorrence of these devices across the international community developed very solidly during the 1990s and led to the Ottawa Convention. Canada, in particular, needs to be commended very strongly for the leader ship role it played in the development of this process. There have been a number of other very significant personalities throughout the world who have led the mobilisation of community opinion on the question of antipersonnel landmines.

A number of speakers have referred to the late Princess Diana, but there are a number of other people who, perhaps more surprising given their backgrounds, have played a prominent role. General Norman Schwarzkopf, the Commander-in-Chief of forces in the Gulf, has spoken out very vigorously on this issue. A person who is visiting this parliament tomorrow I believe—General Fidel Ramos of the Philippines—has also played a most important role in educating the community on these issues.

But the most important activity has come from the non-government organisations—the NGOs—and especially the International Committee of Red Cross. In this respect, the Red Cross is following the noble tradition on which it was founded. It was founded in 1859 in the horrors of another period by Jean Henri Dunant after the Battle of Solferino. This organisation has demonstrated its ongoing strong credentials by the leadership role it has played in the mobilising of community opinion on landmines.
They have been very successful in stigmatising mines. I think it is worth quoting the remarks of a significant Red Cross official in these matters. He says:

Just as law, even international law, is a social creation, so the mobilisation of public consciousness worldwide was a key element in the success of the Ottawa process. When confronted with powerful evidence of the limited military utility of anti-personnel mines, especially in comparison with their enormous humanitarian costs, the public was first appalled, and then persuaded that a total ban was necessary.

I think that is a very accurate description of the process whereby governments generally were led along by public opinion on these important matters. So on 3 December 1997 in Ottawa 125 nations signed the treaty and at that signing a number of very important contributions were made. Secretary-General of the United Nations Annan applauded the treaty as a historic victory for the weak and vulnerable of the world. He went on to say:
It is an alliance—
This is the non-government organisations—
that shamed the world and enlightened it . . . It has, for once, made the international community a living, thriving reality.
At that same ceremony the Canadian Prime Minister made the following comments:

For the first time, the majority of nations of the world will agree to ban a weapon which has been in military use by almost every country in the world. For the first time, a global partnership of governments, international institutions and non-governmental groups have come together—with remarkable speed and spirit—to draft the treaty that we will sign today.

The treaty bans the production, use, stockpiling or transport of antipersonnel mines. It requires the signatories to destroy their stockpiles of mines within four years and remove those deployed within 10. The treaty comes into force with 40 ratifications. My understanding is that the situation presently is that there are 133 signatories and 52 ratifications. The treaty therefore comes into force on 1 March next year, as the parliamentary secretary indicated.

But before we get too carried away with congratulations across the board, I think there are a range of other matters that we need to keep very much in mind. As the parliamentary secretary indicated, there are a number of countries—in fact, the most major military powers—who are still not on board completely in this process. The United States still has some distance to go. The US State Department produced a report earlier this year called Hidden Killers 1998: The Global Landmine Crisis, and in it indicated that the US plans to sign the convention by 2006 if they succeed in identifying a field of suitable alternatives to their antipersonnel landmines and mixed anti-tank systems. President Clinton has made a number of fine rhetorical remarks on the subject but we are still not quite there in terms of the US being on board.

The US continues to perceive a range of problems with respect particularly to their responsibilities on the Korean peninsula. So this seems to me, and I am sure to many members of the House, to be a fine opportunity for Australia, given its special relationship with the United States, to vigorously push the point. Of course, there are a range of other countries, including Russia and China, who are still not on board with the process.

There are a range of matters that need to be dealt with also in relation to the process of de-mining. Recently I came across a report produced by the newsagency Reuters in which there is some considerable discussion about the technologies. The report, amongst other things, says:
Unless affordable new technologies are introduced, sheer manual operations cannot achieve this goal.
That is, the goal of this treaty. It continues:

Open tracts of land . . . may be suitable for mechanical mind clearing technologies . . . But they record an operational efficiency of only 80 per cent, making it necessary for a follow-up by manual work.

The report goes on to talk about the need for the development of high-technology solutions, including magnetic detectors, ground penetrating radar and so on and so forth, as important necessities for the world to achieve some of the targets it has set for itself. I am somewhat sympathetic to that viewpoint. We need to devote the resources to achieving a more active and a quicker process of de-mining, but this leaves us slap bang up against one of the great and horrific ironies of the whole mining debate, and that is the role of a number of the arms manufacturing companies—in fact, the mines manufacturers—in this process of de-mining.

An excellent article appeared in September last year in what I believe is a British publication called the New Internationalist by an author called Paul Donovan. I would like to read a bit of Donovan's discussion on this matter of the technology of de-mining. He says:

It was after the Gulf War that arms manufacturers saw a golden opportunity to diversify and make money out of clearing up the mess that their products had caused in the first place. The growing movement for a ban on land mines has spurred more arms companies to take up this practice known as `double dipping'. While highly paid PR departments have sought to portraying double dipping as a somehow virtuous and redeeming activity, the commercial advantages for the transnational arms corporations have often been lost in the small print. The knowledge a company clearing mines that also still makes them can gain in the field can be of inestimable value.

In 1988 a company called CMS started developing mines for the US military, but after the Gulf War it moved into the `aftermath' (clearance) business. Today CMS is the largest ordinance-clearing company in the US and makes $160 million profits annually. Fred Dibella, CMS Vice President, insists that in Kuwait `we have not cleared up bombs or mines that were of our own manufacture'. However, CMA is owned by Deutsche Aerospace, whose parent company is the German Daimler Benz. Deutsch Aerospace also owns Messerschunurr-Bol, an arms manufacturer, whose products include a new generation of scatterable bombs.
The article goes on:

From South Africa comes another proponent of the `cradle to grave' services offered by some transnational arms manufacturers. Mechem is the research and development wing of Denel, the government-owned arms-manufacturing company. Mechem has won multi-million dollar contracts for the clearing of mines in Mozambique and Angola. Vernon Joynt of Mechem, who has helped design landmines for the South African Defence Force in the past, has seized the opportunity and is now a keen advocate of a ban on land mines.
The article continues:

For 26 years Joynt researched and developed landmines and other equipment, much of which was deployed by South Africa's client groups in Mozambique and Angola. He has proudly boasted that `there are some mines in Angola which no-one will be able to find without our help.' Mr Joynt is also one of the UN's most trusted advisors and well placed to push future technological solutions for the crisis caused by his and other anti-personnel landmines.

So I do not for one moment resile from the importance of Australia in actively encouraging the de-mining process to explore all sorts of technologies and to recognise that many technologies other than the manual will be required. However, one also needs to be aware of the stunning hypocrisy on this issue of many of the people involved in the business. One needs to be very careful to ensure that the technology that is being developed and employed is that which is specifically made for the task rather than that which suits the interests of the arms manufacturers who, as I think we have illustrated, are often precisely the people who have been making the mines and are now seeking to clear them.

In the very short time available to me, I wish to talk about the importance of the arms control agenda continuing to move forward. I think there would be bipartisan agreement that Australia has had a credible and creditable record in a range of areas relating to international activity on weapons of mass destruction—those horrific nuclear, biological and chemical weapons—on which the international community has had to co-operate. However, the landmines issue does raise the question of the need for initiatives with respect to smaller, more conventional weapons.

There is a flood of small arms in the international community that are profoundly destabilising. In aggregate, these small arms other than landmines kill many tens of thousands of people annually. For example, in Albania, where there has been a breakdown of internal security, huge volumes of small arms have flooded onto the markets. Those small arms pop up in many parts of the world. We are aware of the consequences of supplying the Mujaheddin in Afghanistan, in the 1980s, with substantial quantities of materiel—some $6 billion to $9 billion worth.

Large quantities of small arms are popping up in all sorts of places, including Bosnia, Albania, Kosovo, Algeria and Sri Lanka. Sometimes quite sophisticated equipment, like Stinger surface to air missiles, pop up, appearing to come from arms supplied to rebel movements in various ways. I am not seeking to comment one way or the other on the morality or otherwise of this. I am simply saying that, in the small arms area, this flood of international weaponry is presenting an increasing problem for the global community.

The former Secretary-General of the United Nations, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, established a panel on small arms in 1992. That panel recognised the need for some greater transparency in relation to small arms. In 1993 the United Nations established a register of conventional arms, which sought to establish a register of the seven main weapons types, and an increasing number of governments have been participating in that. There have also been suggestions about regional registries of small arms. The Organisation of American States has been one that has taken the lead in that.

Although in debate we often focus on weapons of mass destruction—nuclear, biological or chemical weapons impacting on huge numbers of people at the same time—the horrors that are inflicted by smaller arms should not be overlooked. We ought to encourage this sort of bipartisan discussion in the parliament in the future to ensure that Australia continues to play a prominent role in ensuring that pressure is brought to bear regarding not only landmines but a whole range of other destructive weapons that the international community needs to regulate.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker Gash. How nice it is to see you sitting in the chair. Madam Deputy Speaker, on average, 2,000 people are killed or injured by landmines every month. Fifty years is the average active life of a landmine. 60 million to 70 million landmines are scattered across 70 countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, the Middle East and the Americas. The cost of producing a landmine is $3 to $30. The member for Cowan today showed us one of those small objects that cause so much devastation. The cost of neutralising a landmine is $300 to $1,000. One out of every 236 people in Cambodia is an amputee due to landmine injuries and 20,000 people in Angola are amputees due to landmine injuries. Padraic Convery, in the Guardian Weekly on 4 October 1998, gives a firsthand account of the devastation landmines cause to families and communities in Laos:

speech.para: In one village an entire family was wiped out. The young mother and her four children, aged between two and eight, were all killed by a single unexploded bomb while clearing a field. Only six months earlier her husband had died after striking a `bombie' with his hoe in the same field.

I would like to acknowledge the member for Cowan's knowledge in this area, as demonstrated when he gave his speech today. I feel that anything I could say following that speech would be incredibly superficial. I would also like to acknowledge the speech by the parliamentary secretary, who is responsible for this area, and also the member for Aston who, from his travels in this regard, is aware firsthand of the devastation that these types of mines cause.

As previous speakers have informed us, the purpose of the bill today is to give effect to Australia's obligations as a party to the Convention on the Prohibition of the Use, Stockpiling, Production and Transfer of Anti-Personnel Mines and on their Destruction, otherwise known as the Ottawa Convention. Under the convention, state parties undertake to never, under any circumstances, use antipersonnel mines; to never develop, produce, otherwise acquire, stockpile, retain or transfer to anyone, directly or indirectly, antipersonnel mines; or to assist, encourage or induce in any way anyone to engage in any activity prohibited to a state party under the convention. State parties also undertake to ensure the destruction of all antipersonnel mines in accordance with the provisions of the convention.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon. Alexander Downer, signed the Ottawa treaty on behalf of Australia on 3 December 1997, the first day the treaty was open for signature. Australia is one of 121 countries who signed the treaty when it was first opened and one of 130 who have presently signed it. However, as previous speakers have indicated—the member for Maribyrnong and also, I believe, the parliamentary secretary—key countries in the world have not signed this treaty. So while we here today might congratulate ourselves that there is a treaty, that we are ratifying it and that other countries have and will ratify it, we have to note that major countries in the world have not.

Canada has signed the treaty, but not China; Iceland has signed the treaty, but not Iraq, Israel or Iran; Portugal has signed the treaty, but not Pakistan; Romania has signed the treaty, but not Russia; the United Kingdom has signed the treaty, but not the United States of America. Yet the countries I mentioned that have not signed the treaty are countries that are involved in conflicts, that have enormous power in the world, and that have the capacity to use that power: that would have to be of concern to us all.

The United States has given two official reasons why it has not signed the treaty. It says that antipersonnel mines, APMs, are essential for its defence of the Korean border between South Korea and North Korea. It claims that the danger from North Korea is not its mass of weapons—because, in fact, the US has many more weapons in that area than does North Korea—but the actual numbers of North Koreans who it feels can come over the border. So the US claims that it needs the APMs to keep the North Koreans behind the border. The second reason the US has given for not signing the treaty is that it claims one of its essential weapons is the Gator system. The Gator system is, as I am sure the member for Cowan would know, a system which mixes anti-tank mines with antipersonnel mines. This, according to the United States, is one of its strategic weapons in some areas.

As if to bolster its argument, it also comes up with what are, let us say, justifications—not official reasons—for the position it is taking. The first is that banning mines is not the essential ingredient but clearing them up is. It does seem a little odd that the logic of this argument says, `Look, the problem is not that we're making them and putting them in the ground. The problem is we're not clearing them out of the ground fast enough.'

This argument is taken up by other people who support the United States. For instance, an article by a British Army disposal officer, Paul Jefferson, supports the United States. I refer to this article because it is of interest in the consideration of this topic. His claim is that the issue of banning APMs, as he puts it, `provides employment for bureaucrats, aid workers, lobbyists, lawyers and administrators.' He claims that the problem with APM casualties is an entirely practical one which can only really be addressed by mine clearance—of course ignoring the problem that if we continue to make these mines we will continue to have more and more problems with mine clearance.

He refers to George Soros's foundation, the Open Society. He says that it has put $3 million into the ban campaign but claims that it will not fund clearance mainly because it is seen as too big an issue to get involved in, and at least by promoting the ban they are obtaining publicity. He goes on simply to justify it by saying:

Where concerted clearance has been undertaken, casualty figures have fallen off dramatically; more clearance could have been going on if the quick-fix, feel-good solution of the ban lobby did not divert attention and resources.

As I said, I find it a particularly strange argument that we do not have to ban the mines because our real problem is getting them out of the ground—of course the real problem is getting them out of the ground—and I have referred to the number that are in the ground. But the obvious corollary is that we have to stop making mines and we have to stop putting them in the ground—even with the modern, sophisticated techniques which enable people to map and locate them.

Another unofficial argument of the United States is that it would ban landmines if it could replace them with non-lethal mines. The types of non-lethal mines that have been suggested are gas bombs, teargas bombs, loud noise bombs and one that produces a particularly offensive foam when stepped on. But those suggestions have again been rejected because such mines do not instil enough fear into the heart of the enemy.

The US President has been, if nothing else, equivocal on this issue. Feeling very conscious of the fact that the US has not signed the treaty, in May this year he did signal that the US government may sign the Ottawa Convention in 2006 but only if detonators to existing APMs have been developed by then. But the promise is fairly meaningless anyway, as I fear President Clinton will be long gone by 2006.

For Australia, the signing of the Ottawa treaty followed the commitment given by the Australian government in April 1996 to support a global ban on antipersonnel landmines and imposed an indefinite suspension on the operational use of these weapons by the Australian Defence Force. Australia is a longstanding contributor to international efforts to help mine affected countries. Most assistance goes to Cambodia, Laos, Angola, Mozambique and Afghanistan—areas where the effects of landmines are particularly severe.

In Cambodia, Australian aid has helped cut the number of people killed or maimed by APMs by two-thirds. Over 525,000 mines have already been cleared. Australian soldiers and civilian personnel are working to provide training and organisational support to help Cambodians clear landmines using the latest Australian technology. So vast and time consuming is the clearance task that in the interim Austcare is teaching villages how to live safely with landmines. Using mine detection dogs, these contaminated areas are being signposted and people educated about how to move and live safely amongst them.

According to Austcare's mine action consultant, Bill van Ree, there are 1,500 square kilometres of known contaminated areas in Cambodia. At present, Australia is capable of clearing only about 20 square kilometres per year, which emphasises the need we have to increase the technology in this area. Australian de-mining expertise and technology is world renowned. A key to the success of the de-mining program in Cambodia is a mine detector invented by a South Australian company called Minelab.

Since 1991, the Australian government has also funded landmine awareness and de-mining projects in Afghanistan where each day 10 Afghans are killed or maimed by landmines. With 90 per cent of Afghanistan's mined areas in agricultural fields, irrigation canals and grazing areas, economic recovery will be severely hampered until those mines are removed.

Similarly, in Angola, the Australian government is helping to remove some 10 million landmines still in the ground. Again, in Angola, the sniffer dogs are being used to identify the areas that are mined. In Mozambique, where landmines were used extensively in the civil war that ended in 1992, Australians are working as technical advisers, training nearly 500 Mozambiquans in de-mining techniques. Since the de-mining program began in 1994, over 200 hectares of land has been cleared, with over 15,000 landmines located and destroyed.

By 2005, the Australian government anticipates it will have spent more than $100 million on de-mining and related programs. I do recall that the member for Cowan has asked about the spending of that money and for some more information from the minister, which I am sure will be forthcoming. To emphasise the priority it places on building a solution to the global landmine problem, the Australian government appointed a Special Representative on De-mining in March 1998, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon. Kathy Sullivan MP, whom we heard earlier in this debate.

Mrs Sullivan has played a key role in ensuring Australia's de-mining efforts are coordinated to maximise their impact in the field. She is also working to encourage the most effective global coordination of international donor resources to de-mining victim assistance projects and landmine awareness education. On 12 October this year, the Minister for Foreign Affairs announced the government's Destroy a Minefield initiative. This program enables individuals, schools, community groups, businesses and associations to participate directly in solving the landmines problem by `adopting' active landmines selected by the United Nations as having a high priority for clearance.

The Destroy a Minefield program will use funds from the Princess Diana Trust Fund set up to collect the sales tax revenue raised from the Elton John Candle in the Wind tribute CD. An Australian non-government organisation will be selected to implement and administer the Destroy a Minefield program. This NGO will seek sponsors in the Australian community to raise the necessary funds to clear adopted minefields. Perhaps collection could be taken by the parliamentarians as a start.

The $200,000 allocated from the Princess Diana Trust Fund will be the final allocation of the $793,000 of sales tax revenue raised by the CD. The government will also contribute an additional $200,000 to the program on top of the trust fund allocation. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker Gash, I congratulate you and, since this is my first speech in the 39th Parliament, could you also pass my congratulations on to the Speaker. I am very pleased to join other members in supporting the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 . In particular, one of our new colleagues, the member for Cowan, who is obviously an expert in these matters, has made a very good contribution, ensuring that all details are raised with respect to questions of this kind.

speech.para: I want to make some brief comments because we have been asked to limit our comments so that many people who wish to speak on the record in relation to this matter are able to do so. I think it is very important that we discuss the two aspects of this issue: the first aspect is to do with trying to prevent new landmines being put down—these bombs are put in place, explode and kill people, the vast majority of whom are innocent people. The second aspect is to try to remove those landmines that are already in place.

These two issues need to be confronted by the international community—and that the conference in Ottawa made a very substantial start in doing so is very heartening. But we need to ask ourselves: how did we get into this terrible, dreadful situation where so many people around the world have been and are being killed by these mines?

The answer to that question requires us to reflect on the terrible history of the world over this century. Although this century started off with great ambitions for peace and tranquillity for humanity, it has been the most bloody century certainly for more than a thousand years. As a result of that fact, we have developed weapons of mass destruction. Unfortunately, those weapons include antipersonnel mines—and in some ways they are probably the most vicious of all. Of course, the most horrific weapons are the atomic ones. But the point about atomic weapons is that, even during the balance of terror situation—with the exception of what happened during the Second World War to Japan—they have not been used. The problem with antipersonnel mines is that they have been used extensively and they have maimed and killed many, many people throughout the world in many, many conflicts.

It is interesting that nowadays we tend to say, `Well, the enlightened nations wish to sign this treaty.' But we would not have been put in the position of having to sign this treaty if not for the fact that many nations in the world participated, sometimes unthinkingly, in that dreadful conflict known as the Cold War. The conflict over the Cold War was one of the most unnecessary in human history. Even though it did not lead to a world war, having come close a few times, it nevertheless led to many localised wars and many civil conflicts and civil wars within countries.

For example, in Mozambique there was a dreadful civil war which was based essentially on Cold War ideologies. As a result of that conflict, many of these antipersonnel mines were put into place, as was mentioned by the previous speaker. The unfortunate situation now is that we are still desperately trying to remove those mines from Mozambique and, even though there now is relative peace in that country, we still have a situation where innocent people are being killed.

That raises the question of whether, in fact, we can do something as a civilisation to ensure that in the future, irrespective of the nature of our conflicts, whatever they may be—even if they lead to civil war or war between nations—we can be in a situation in which we are able to say, `We will not have these weapons; we will not use these weapons.' That is the situation that we need to put into place. That is why the Ottawa agreement was very important—but it needs to be signed by all governments, and it needs to be enforced.

This is where we are extremely disappointed with the position taken by some of the great powers—the United States, Russia, China, India and several others. Although Australia certainly has taken very important initiatives—and both parties in this parliament can take credit for these initiatives—and has a proud record in recent times in relation to this issue, we need to put it to our allies with whom we have good relations, such as the United States and others, that it is very important for them to sign this agreement.

Of course, the military in every country, especially in the big countries, will always have excuses for wanting to have all sorts of equipment and hardware available. It is one thing to have military hardware for use in an honourable conflict—to the extent that such conflicts can possibly exist, and I do not believe that they can in the long term; but let us say that we can at least talk about a relatively honourable conflict—but there is nothing honourable about these mines. It is the most dishonourable thing to put these into the ground and kill innocent people, civilians, on whatever side. These weapons should be banned. We therefore need to proceed to do everything that we can at an international level to push along the process that has been initiated by the Ottawa agreement.

Let me make it clear: we are doing some good things in Australia, but we need to use our international muscle in relation to this matter. As I have said, we are facing the 21st century and we need at least to ask ourselves: do we want a repetition of the disasters of the 20th century through resorting to weapons which were found to be unacceptable, such as biological weapons of warfare, chemical weapons of warfare and these terrible mines? The answer is that we do not. Irrespective of whatever differences we have, irrespective of whatever conflicts may arise in the future, we should never resort again to these sorts of actions.

That leaves us with the question: how are we going to achieve such an agreement with the big powers? I think that an initiative needs to be taken to push the Ottawa process further—perhaps an initiative at the United Nations General Assembly, even at the level of the Security Council. Why not raise this issue at the highest levels of the United Nations, including in the Security Council, and say, `Look, as an act of showing that we are committed to the universal declaration of human rights, that we are committed to a peaceful world, that we are committed to positive developments in international relations in the 21st century, why don't we, as a very important symbolic act, before the end of this century, put a ban on these weapons that is universal and accepted by all nations?'

I think that is a worthy goal that Australia with other nations ought to pursue at the United Nations—and I am sure that Canada would be very, very interested in also pursuing such an initiative. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has done worthy work in this area, as has the parliamentary secretary, the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and other people who have been involved; they ought to be congratulated for what they have done up to this point. But we can do more and we should do more; and we should raise the matter at the United Nations and try to use our influence in raising it with the great powers.

There is the question of what we are going to do with those dreadful weapons that are in the ground already. There are an estimated 20 million landmines in so many different countries. What is required is a cooperative effort with those countries that have signed the agreement. They all need to be prepared to put in something to help in this process. Some of them are poor countries, so they may be excused. But those countries which belong to the OECD or the so-called First World countries ought to use their finances to help to clear those mines. Because, while those mines remain, children and innocent people are going to be killed.

I am not a particular fan of the royalty, but I have to say that Princess Diana was a very honourable woman for taking up this cause. What she did in making this cause known to the world community was very important. But we have to follow through with the kind of work that she initiated through governments and through organisations in our community, including Australian non-government organisations that are wanting to pursue this work. It is very important in the final analysis to do everything that we can to clear these mines and to ensure that people can live in relative peace. It must be a dreadful phenomenon to think that most of your land is covered with these awful weapons.

I want to make a point about the situation in Afghanistan. The conflict in Afghanistan has become one of those forgotten wars where people are killed every day. We have been talking about clearing mines, but mines are being put in place in Afghanistan because of the struggle that is going on there. It is time the international community took more of an interest in the conflict in Afghanistan and in other conflicts where people are using these weapons. It is not enough to say, `We should not have them, and we have signed an agreement saying that we do not want to have them.' What about doing something about those conflicts in the world where these weapons are being used here today? I think we need to take in interest in the situation in Afghanistan. The international community needs to take an interest in it. The same is true of those areas of the world where there are regional conflicts of this kind.

I am very proud that this parliament has introduced this legislation and that we have taken a bipartisan position on it. I believe it shows that Australia is an honourable country in relation to this matter. Our example needs to be followed by others. We need, as I said at the beginning, to put some pressure on our friends who have not signed the agreement to do so. As I also mentioned, we need to focus on those areas of the world where these weapons are being used today to try to ensure that we get peace in those places and to stop those weapons being used in the future.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker Gash, congratulations on your appointment to the Speaker's panel. I look forward to your fair and reasonable conduct from the high office that you are now holding. I am delighted to take part in this discussion today. Like the honourable member for Calwell, I celebrate the bipartisan debate that we are having at the moment. It is worth reflecting in the course of this debate that a lot of what we have before us came as a result of the creature of this place—that is, the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties tabled in February last year entitled Restrictions on the use of blinding laser weapons and landmines . In that particular report there were many recommendations which have been taken up by the executive government. I congratulate the executive for listening to all sides of politics involved in the treaties committee.

speech.para: The very sobering task of that inquiry has left a mark on me. When I came to this place, I never imagined that I would be talking about or participating in foreign affairs issues. I came here with the basic goal of representing the views and concerns of the electorate of Moreton and the people within it. But being appointed to the treaties committee broadened my horizons a great deal. It also gave me an opportunity to keep a promise that I made to a number of different groups in my electorate—for example, the Social Justice Catholic Committee, the Red Cross, Amnesty and others—that were concerned as are all members in this place about the use of these dreadful weapons.

I was particularly pleased to note that on 15 April 1996 one of the very first acts of the Howard government was to announce support for the global ban on the production and stockpile, use and transfer of antipersonnel landmines. That we have signed the protocol in Ottawa and that we have fulfilled our obligations in this legislation here today is a terrific thing. But the use of antipersonnel landmines, as the members for Calwell, Cowan, Hindmarsh and the parliamentary secretary have all made note of, continues.

These are easy to make weapons. They are relatively cheap weapons. They are not designed to kill as much as they are designed to maim. They are designed to wreak psychological havoc on retreating armies or personnel that come across these landmines in the act of retreat or withdrawal. These landmines are left behind. Children trip over them. Some are designed, primarily by the way they are positioned, so that children come in contact with them. Some are designed so that an arm is blown off or a leg is blown off or somebody is maimed rather than directly killed as a result of coming into contact with these antipersonnel landmines.

They are vile, cowardly and horrible weapons. We all agree with that. It is a great pity, though, that a number of armies in the world and amongst the superpowers continue to keep open the option of using them. The fact that China, the Russian Federation, Israel and major nations would actually keep those sorts of options open to them is abhorrent. Nations such as Iraq and Iran are involved in conflict—I do not think the word `understandable' is quite right in the context of anything to do with antipersonnel landmines, but perhaps it is explainable as to why they may keep the option open. Egypt, India and Pakistan are the sorts of nations that still have access to these particular weapons.

The fact that Australia plays a practical role in their removal in nations afflicted by the Indo-Chinese war—nations in our general region—is something about which we can hold our head very high on the international stage. We have gained a great deal of expertise in the task of removing landmines, and we have shown the world leadership on the issue of not using them.

Some of the evidence we found in the inquiries of the Treaties Committee is worth revisiting and reporting again to the parliament as a worthwhile contribution to this discussion. As I said, landmines are easily available, low-technology items, made up of a casing, a detonator and material discharged by the detonation. They are cheap to make, buy and lay. They can be made in kitchens, garages or fields. In fact, the committee saw one at work on 6 December 1996.

These mines are not designed to kill people; they are designed to injure them. Evidence from Dr William Maley pointed out that a military force can be disabled much more effectively if it has a significant number of injured rather than dead to be concerned about. Leaving the dead in the battlefield is one thing, but leaving the injured is another. Human compassion slows down the progress or otherwise of the army.

Consider also this other bit of evidence: for every mine cleared, for every mine taken out and disposed of, 20 more are laid—20 more are laid for every one that is cleared! According to United Nations estimates, it would take 1,100 years to clear the active landmines already in place, about $33 billion to rid the world of them. In fact, antipersonnel landmines continue to maim and kill innocent civilians—normally and unfortunately in too many cases they are children—indiscriminately long after hostilities have ceased. About 30 people per day are killed and up to 60 people per day are maimed in the world today. That is the reality.

One example given in the report was that Libyans are still dying from mines that were laid during the Second World War. Between 1945 and the mid-1970s in Poland, some 4,000 civilian deaths and 9,000 injuries were attributed to mines, although some 15 million had already been cleared at great expense. They are the sorts of statistics that are damning, damning especially of those nations that have turned their backs on this particular treaty and this action that is before us today.

Yes, they should be banned. The member for Calwell is right in his aspiration that we should just ban them. But, as every member of this House would know, a simple ban takes the legitimate users out of the equation and the illegitimate users continue. The black market, if you like, on landmines would simply grow from a world-wide ban, but the aspiration is right. It is certainly up to decent nations like ours to send the signal we are sending as a result of this legislation.

Although I have set the case for why a simple ban is not the simple answer, and while the UN has set the case that $33 billion and 1,100 years would be involved in removing the mines that are currently laid, we should be looking at those simple, low cost ingredients that make up these dreadful weapons and who makes those ingredients. I suspect there is a role for each member of parliament to play if they come across evidence that suggests that the componentry of any of those household electronics companies that we might know, that we might subscribe to or that we might use, are in fact turning up in landmines. We should be prepared to take action against companies who are not taking the responsibility that they should undertake to ensure that their components manufactured and distributed are being used properly. It will take a great deal of time, but perhaps that is one way to bring about the aspirations the member for Calwell has offered today.

The parts in the mines are one aspect; those who continue to use them are another—and there is a range of possibilities open to the world community to deal with those nations who continue to snub their noses at decent conduct. While you can negotiate with the United States, with India and Pakistan—I am sure—and with China and Russia—I am also confident—and also with Israel, some nations such as Iraq in current times have shown their complete unwillingness to comply with world demands on their conduct.

The challenge is before us. It is a big challenge. It is not an easily realisable result, but what we are doing here today is an extension of what the Treaties Committee recommended 18 months ago. It was a process I was proud to be a part of, and I think all members in this place should be pleased that the government had the initiative to put in place that Treaties Committee process so that the views of people from my electorate and from other electorates all around this nation can be heard on such important matters. By passing this legislation today, this parliament will be sending a signal to the world stage that Australia is prepared to put its name to decency, honesty and integrity and to demand the same from some of its friends who, unfortunately, are a bit reluctant to act.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be involved in this non-partisan debate and welcome the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 . As the member for Cowan and others after him have emphasised, the antipersonnel mine is an explosive device which is developed and designed to maim. Let me reiterate, as speakers have done before me, some of the facts and statistics relating to these hidden killers. These statistics need constant repetition to ensure the banning of all landmines is kept high on the political agenda.

speech.para: There are over 600 types of antipersonnel landmines. They vary in shape, size, material of construction, amount and type of explosive used, and the way in which they are placed—some a few inches underground, some just on top of the ground, and some located above the ground. Detection and deactivation of these mines is a slow, tedious and dangerous process. Most humanitarian operations are done by hand with a metal detector, probes and a trowel.

A 1994 report estimated that the world was littered with 80 million to 110 million land mines, and that each year only 80,000 were being detected and removed while 2½ million were still being planted. The conservative estimate of the number of people maimed and killed yearly by landmines is 24,000. That is one victim every 20 minutes. The 110 million mines are lying hidden today in approximately 64 countries, infesting the world's former and contemporary hot spots. The average cost of these landmines is $3 each; the average cost for the search and removal of one landmine is $1,000. The removal of all landmines would cost an estimated $110 billion.
As well as the cost involved in the search and removal of these instruments of destruction, there are many unseen costs to human life and our society. These include:
The medical costs for the treatment and rehabilitation of victims: even when services are available, this can take years and deplete scarce medical resources in these poor countries.

The cost of refugees and the repatriation of these people: the presence of landmines impedes the return of refugees and the rebuilding of war-torn societies, which prolong the consequences of war and armed conflict.

Economic considerations: the prevalence of landmines in the majority of these countries prevents the fullest utilisation of farmland, destroys livestock and disrupts markets and production patterns. A further ravaging impact of the proliferation of landmines is the vast areas of arable land which have become no-man's-land.

The presence of landmines of course inhibits tourism and other potential investment and development opportunities: by retarding economic recovery and reconstruction in these regions, the presence of landmines increases tensions and instability, and fewer resources are available for reconstruction and redevelopment.

Environmental impacts: alongside the immediate and tragic impact on human life, the detonation of landmines also irreparably damages wildlife, forests and surrounding environmental resources, with far-reaching consequences for both economic and social development. Minefields often become breed ing grounds for disease because they are left untended.

Security implications: while ever landmines are present they inhibit negotiations between countries which are seeking to restore peace and move towards post-conflict recovery and reconstruction. They also impede humanitarian assistance efforts in the peace process by preventing delivery of urgently needed services and supplies, and discouraging potential investors.

Over 70 per cent of landmines in the last 30 years have been laid during civil strife and rebellion in various regions. The landmine has been a handy and inexpensive weapon for terrorists and guerilla outfits. They have been used indiscriminately to cause fear among the civilian population. With the intention of causing disruption in society and in the pursuit of political and economic objectives rather than military aims, the weapons have been planted around water wells, schools, electricity and power generation units, bridges and over vast agricultural areas—making life miserable during insurgency and later blocking the rehabilitation of refugees in the wake of peace settlements.

After foreign soldiers, arms suppliers and military advisers have left the scene, the grim reminders of the past in the battlefields of insurgents, guerillas and government forces during the Cold War are the numerous cases of amputation due to injuries caused by landmines in unmarked and unmapped locations.

The culmination of the world movement to ban landmines was the signing by 125 nations, including Australia, of a treaty on 3 December 1997 in Ottawa—the Ottawa Convention. Australia's foreign minister, Alexander Downer, who signed that treaty, indicated in May 1996 that Australia would pursue a total ban on the manufacture, stockpile, use and transfer of antipersonnel landmines. It has taken this government over 2½ years to introduce this legislation, which now has the bipartisan support of this parliament to ratify that convention. However, I believe that the complete ratification of that convention by this government is still in doubt. There is no indication either within this bill or from the government that Australia is fully committed to the convention under all circumstances. It seems the way has been left open for the Australian defence forces to use landmines in areas of strategic necessity. In May 1996, the then defence minister, Ian McLachlan, said:

Only in case of a substantial deterioration in our strategic circumstances, in which Australia's security was under threat and the denial of an anti-personnel landmine capability to the ADF would result in additional Australian casualties and damage to vital infrastructure would the suspension be reviewed.
I do not think that is a complete, 100 per cent commitment, and I am sorry about that.

I also have a concern over the ambiguity of section 7 (3), which does appear to provide a loophole for the use of landmines by the ADF. Australia cannot be prosecuted for using landmines if it engages in military action with a country that has not signed the Ottawa Convention. There is also provision for Australia to stockpile landmines to the extent necessary for experimentation in deactivating techniques.

The achievement of the 2010 goal of the complete removal of landmines does require significant inroads into the effective application of demining technology. This bill does address in part the necessity to apply resources to the technological challenge posed by these silent killers. While the government seems reluctant to allocate adequate resources toward much needed technological advancement in this area, it must be argued that, if the Department of Defence is to escape the ravages of funding cuts imposed on other areas of spending by this government, as the Prime Minister so proudly boasts it will, all Australians should be assured that there will be no shortage of funding for developing new demining technology.

The member for Moreton, who spoke before me, also referred to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties entitled Restrictions on the use of blinding laser weapons and landmines. In that report was the recommendation to the government that the Defence Science and Technology Organisation be funded to assist in the development of safer, faster and more efficient ways of reducing the number of landmines. The government's response to this very worthy recommendation was that `the DSTO's charter does not extend to the development of equipment and technology to the production stage'. So this government seems willing to promote a worldwide ban on landmines, but it is not willing to pursue such practical measures which could significantly contribute to this cause.

The parliamentary secretary also referred to the unpredictability and the indiscriminatory impact of antipersonnel landmines, which has recently been highlighted in Central America. These countries and their people, who have been tragically devastated by the fury of Hurricane Mitch, now face a deadly new problem as floodwaters and mud slides have unearthed and scattered landmines downstream and over river banks in Honduras and Nicaragua. I am glad the government has finally brought this legislation to this House. I hope that some of the ambiguities that I have outlined are addressed in the near future.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 , whilst I do not for one moment question the sincerity of the member for Charlton, there are some factual errors in what she has said. The first is that there is not some sort of provision or escape hatch left open for the use of landmines. The mines may be only acquired and used specifically for the training of personnel who might then be used for demining in other countries.

speech.para: In terms of legislation being brought forward, until the Ottawa Convention was agreed to, you could not bring forward legislation to give effect to the commitments that Australia had made. When the initial negotiations were undertaken prior to the convention being signed, there were countries—of which Australia was one at the time—that wanted to leave open the possibility of use for extreme and hopefully unforeseen circumstances. But this bill says quite clearly:
(1) A person is guilty of an offence if:
(a) the person places an anti-personnel mine under, on or near the ground or other surface area; or
(b) the person is knowingly in the possession of an anti-personnel mine; or
(c) the person develops, produces or otherwise acquires an anti-personnel mine; or
(d) the person stockpiles anti-personnel mines; or
(e) the person physically moves an anti-personnel mine; or
(f) the person transfers ownership or control of an anti-personnel mine, whether directly or indirectly, to another person.
I am sure the minister will also respond to some of these things at the conclusion of the debate.

Australia is a signatory to the Ottawa landmines convention and as such we are now one of 130 countries working towards a global culture of repugnance towards mines, those who use them and the human devastation that they produce. Landmines cause death or injury every 20 minutes; that is, during the time it takes each speaker to make a contribution to the debate on this bill, another life will be lost or another body grievously injured—that person being someone's father or mother, son or daughter, brother or sister. Half of the people who are injured or killed by landmines are children. In fact, 10 Afghans are maimed or killed every day.

Conflict and wars of one form or another are bad enough, but there can be no justification at all for the continued use of these devices whose victims are invariably civilians, frequently long after conflicts are officially declared over, as the member for Cowan said in his opening address. The convention does allow signatories to the convention to maintain a limited number of mines, as I said, for the development of, and training in, mine clearance techniques. If Australian military personnel are to continue their humanitarian work of clearing mines, there is clearly a need for continued maintenance of the skills base so essential for confronting nations who continue to employ these weapons.

It is estimated that between 60 million to 70 million landmines are scattered across 70 countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, the Middle East and the Americas. The average life of a landmine is 50 years. Each is produced for as little as $3 to $30, whereas neutralising a mine costs somewhere between $300 and $1,000. One out of 236 people in Cambodia is an amputee, as are 20,000 Afghans, thanks to landmines.

Under this Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 , Australia, along with the other 130 signatories, undertakes never under any circumstance to use, transfer, manufacture and stockpile antipersonnel mines. Recognising that the Ottawa treaty is not the only solution to this global plague, Australia must continue to initiate and support mechanisms that bring the major traditional producers, users and exporters of landmines into the process if there is to be an enduring solution. I think this is one area where Australia, all our governments and all of us who are in this parliament can do more to bring a meaningful resolution.

Australia is a longstanding contributor to international efforts to help de-mine affected countries. Most assistance goes, unsurprisingly, to Cambodia, Laos, Angola, Mozambique and Afghanistan. These areas are the most affected and mined. Australian personnel not only engage directly in mine clearance but also participate in the training of local people in most of the major landmine clearance projects around the world. Australian aid—that is, money we send overseas—also works for the United Nations, with Red Cross and non-government organisations working to rebuild the lives of landmine victims. It funds education and awareness programs for farmers and their families. In particular, we play a key role in teaching children about the danger of landmines. Many children mistake them for toys, which is understandable. Again, I refer to the opening address of the member for Cowan. By the year 2005, Australia will have spent more than $100 million in support of de-mining and related programs. That is a significant amount of money. I am reminded of comments made by the former member for Oxley, Mrs Pauline Hanson, and by Mr David Oldfield, who seems to have assumed the role of public spokesperson for her party. I recall how Mrs Hanson, in her maiden speech, said, amongst other things, that we should stop sending money overseas and that we should stop foreign aid. She said that as long as we had unemployed people in Australia we should spend the money on ourselves. Over the last three months, at least on two public occasions, Mr Oldfield has said in relation to the United Nations that for Australia it is `a one-way street'. Mr Oldfield said on radio 2UE and on Channel 9's Today show that Australia gets nothing out of the UN and that we put money in but we get nothing back.

This goes to the very heart of what sort of nation we want to be. Do we really want to be people who turn our backs on the rest of the world, be it in providing de-mining programs, education infrastructure, development programs or whatever? I remember Mrs Hanson talking about charity beginning at home. It is important that, as Australians, we understand that charity does begin at home. However, it does not end there. If you really want to measure the strength of human beings and nations, you can do so reliably by looking at the care, concern and compassion they show to those whose needs are greater than their own.

When the Salvation Army, Community Aid Abroad, Austcare or any similar charitable organisation knock on our door, we do not try to inculcate in the next generation a value that says, `I am not getting anything out of it this year so I am not giving anything to you.'
